notesStmt.note: Reproduction of original in Huntington Library.
The main plot is almost a translation of Molières L'Avare, but many new characters and scenes have been added. cf. "Reader," 3d prelim. leaf; Miles, Influence of Molier̀e, p. 234.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE MISER: A COMEDY ACTED By His Majesties Servants, AT THE Theater Royal. Written by THOMAS SHADWELL.
LONDON, Printed for Hobart Kemp, at the sign of the Ship in the upper Walk of the New Exchange, 1672.

div.head: To the Right Honourable CHARLES Lord Buckhurst, Gentleman of His MAJESTIES BED-CHAMBER.
div.p:
THE Favour which your Lordship was pleased to shew to this Play, I value more than all the loud Applauses of a Theater: Nor can it be less esteemed by any man that has had the honour of knowing your Lordships Person, or the pleasure of reading the diversions of your pen. It seems by your obliging kindness to the Poets, and your great example in writing, as if you were design'd by Heaven, among many other great uses, for the sustaining of declining Poetry. This consideration, with the boldness which your frequent favours
have given me, pull the trouble of this Dedication upon you. You see, my Lord, the danger of encouraging any of us, who are too apt without it to use the names of great men for the defence of our weaknesses and follies; nay, some are so arrogant to believe their injurious Dedications competent returns for all the Obligations they receive from the generosity of their Patrons. But I, my Lord, have been too much obliged by you to think of making any return: all that I can do, is to beg leave to make an humble acknowledgment of all your favours; and to take this occasion to publish my self to the World,

closer.signed: Your Lordships Most Obliged Humble Servant, THOMAS SHADWELL.

div.p: THE Foundation of this Play I took from one of Moliere's called L' Avare; but that having too few persons, and too little action for an English Theater, I added to both so much, that I may call more than half of this Play my own: and I think I may say without vanity, that Moliere's part of it has not suffer'd in my hands, nor did I ever know a French Comedy made use of by the worst of our Poets, that was not better'd by 'em. 'Tis not barrenness of wit or invention, that makes us borrow from the French, but laziness; and this was the occasion of my making use of L' Avare. This Play, as it was wrote in less than a moneth, and was the last Play that was Acted at the Kings Theater in Covent-garden, before the fatal fire there; the great hast I made in writing it, that made me very doubtful of the success of it, which was the reason that at first I did not own it, but conceal'd my Name. I have resolved to take my leave of long Prefaces, and will give you no farther trouble here, for fear you should find too much afterwards.

div.head: PROLOGUE
[The Authors Name not being then known.]
div.l: OUR Poet never doubts the good success
Of Farce that's in half French, half English dress:
And this was made with little pains and wit,
As any cobling Poet e're wrote yet,
And therefore he's resolv'd not to submit.
The Fortune of his Fellows he has seen,
Who in dull Farce have so successful been,
That could he write true wit, he is in doubt
Whether you would endure to sit it out.
But though he has no wit, he has some shame,
And stealing from the French conceals his name.
French Plays, in which true wit's as rarely found
As Mines of Silver are in English ground;
A foolish Marquiss, or his knavish man,
Or some poor Pudden fool's the best they can.—
But stay, I've been to bold; methinks I see
The English Monsieurs rise in mutiny,
Crying confound him, does he damn French Plays,
The only Pieces that deserve the Bayes:
France that on fashions does strict Laws impose,
The Universal Monarchy for Cloaths,
That rules our most important part, our dress,
Should rule our wit, which is a thing much less.
But Messieurs he says, farther to provoke ye,
He would as soon be Author of Tu Quoque,
As any Farce that e're from France was sent,
And all consider'd 'tis a complement,
And yet he hopes the advantages they gain,
That he may please ye with small stock of brain:
For our good natur'd Nation thinks it fit,
To count French Toys, good Wares; French nonsence, wit.

list.head: The Actors Names.
list.item: Bellamour A Gentleman in disguise, his true name Raines, and servant to Gold. but a lover of Theodora.
Rant and Hazzard Two Gamesters of the Town.
Roger Iames and William Servants to Goldingham.

div.head: ACT. 1.
SCE. 1.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p:
WHat a devil makes thee in so musty a humour? Thou art as dull and dump •••
as a fellow that had been drunk over night with Ale, and had done no ••• ng but drunk Coffee, talked Politicks, and read Gazettes all this morning.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Hast lost thy money, or thy wench?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Nay faith Hazard, if he has lost his money, I am sure he has lost his wench, in spight of the noble vertue of constancy.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Come Theodore a lucky hand or two at the Groom Porters, will get thee as good a Mistriss as any about the Town.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: No pox on't they are kept so high by foolish elder Brothers, that poor younger Brothers must despaire of 'em.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: No Rant, thou art mistaken, the Elder Brothers are so kind to keep 'em for the younger, that can not do't for themselves; they are civil to the one for love, and the other for money.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: I am not of your opinion, there was never so much ready money and so little love stirring, as at this time.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p:
Faith then we (that have but shallow purses) must three or four club for one, shee'l serve us all, considering how we drink. Come Theodore be not melancholy, if thou hast
lost thy Mistriss, I'le club with thee for another.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: So Gentlemen, • his Dialogue run • off very smartly; you had rehearsed it before, but I find you have the effects of last nights debauch upon you, and are hot headed this morning, what else should make you think me melancholy?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Come faith, thou art.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I must confess Gentlemen I am not in so brisk a humour as to leap over Joynt-stooles, or come over a stick for the King, or any of those pretty frolicks; but I have no trouble, unless you will create me one.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I am so far from that, that I'le tell thee news that will rejoyce the heart of thee, if thou wert as dumpish as a young Spark that is newly denyed to be trusted for a white Periwig.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Prethee what's that?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: That which I am sure you'l bite at.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: There is the most delicate, charming creature, come to lye over against us in Bow-street! Oh tis a melting Girle, she looks as if she would dissolve like an Anchovee in Claret.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: She would relish better (when a man has the hot fit upon him) than small Beer in a Feaver.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Than small Beer a pox on't, she would be more welcome to thee than a Reprieve would, if thou wert just now trolling out Hopkins and Sternhold upon a Ladder.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: You are mighty witty, and, full of similies; but who the Devil is this incomparable Lady?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Pox on't, thou art as testy as an old Leane Judge fasting, upon the Bench, between eleven and twelve.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I'le put him into a better humour; with this young Lady, is Mrs▪ Cheatly, party per pale Match-maker, and Baud, got acquainted, and has promised to bring her to a Ball at the Bear at Charing-Cross, where you know there is a very convenient Couch.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Oh she's a delicate bit for him that can get her, she's fit for one of us honest Fellows to debauch, and for a dull rich Fellow (born to the drudgery of Plowing Land and getting Heirs) to Marry.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: But (if you be not too much transported to tell me) Pray who is this young Lady?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Why, 'tis one Isabella that lyes over against our Lodgeing at the Blew Balcone.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: 'Sdeath what said he?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: How now, are you nettled? Gad I'le lay my life this Rogue has been before-hand with us.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: No faith Gentlemen, but this Lady I have seen, and know she has some qualities very unfit for your Company.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: What are those Man?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Dam'd unfashionable qualities, call'd vertue, and modesty.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Pish, but if she be not too much season'd with vertue in this warm age, she cannot keep long.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Indeed but she will, in spight of that Villanous Seducer Cheatly, whose Clutches scarce any young Lady can scape.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Prethee speak not against thy Mother-in-Law, thou hadst the debauching of her Daughter Lettice.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I the debauching of her; she was debauch'd from her Mothers Womb, she has it ex Traduce.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: I'le hold thee ten pound Cheatly brings this Lady to Supper, for all her vertue, and modesty.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: 'Sdeath Sir, I know she cannot, shall not do't.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: On my Conscience he's in downright abominable love with this Lady.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Well, because you are a couple of good honest Fellows, that is, as farr as those that use Cater-deuce-azes, and smooth Boxes, and Cheat at Dice, can be.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Cheat? we do play a little upon advantage I confess, (as many people of Quality and most Gentlemen that are Gamesters do.)

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Indeed false Boxes, and Dice are an advantage, but to let that pass: I will prevent your Errour, with this Isabella I am unreasonably and desperately in Love.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: But 'its in an honourable way, I hope, not at all inclining to wedlock.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Yes faith, I am in Love, even to Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p:
Pox on thee for an unseasonable Fellow, to think of Matrimony in this age, when an honest Woman is almost
asham'd to shew her Face, she finds triumphant Punk so much preferred before her.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: If we, honest Fellows of the Town, go on as we begin, honest Women will come to be Ston'd in the Streets.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: What, thou art turn'd a publick spirited Fellow, I warrant, and wisely considerest, that people are wanting in England, and that more frequent Marriage would be a means of Propagation.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: And I believe thou hast subtilly found out that whoreing, and Monasteries, are as great causes of their wanting people in Spain, as their West Indian Colonies.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: None of these politick considerations I assure you; and yet ever since I saw Isabella I care less for a Whore, than you do for an honest Woman: Yet you shall find I am not wholly unfit for your Company, I have not given over all sins at once, for if you'l go before and bespeak, Dinner at Shatolins you shall see how I'le sowce you in Burgundy.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Well, wee'l go and hope, by the helpe of Burgundy, to recover your Senses again.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Have a care of loosing your own.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: That we may have no advantage over you, wee'l each of us drink 2 or 3 Beer-glasses, before you come.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Adieu.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: How now Bellamour, where's my Father.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, he's busie upon a question in Arithmetick, to see how much 15 l. comes to in seven years, with use upon use.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: What use his fifty in the hundred, that he takes of Herb-women and Oyster-women? For which they Pawn, their dear Rings, and Wedding Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, he's willing to make the most of his money.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Has he taken account what Dripping has been sold this week to the Kitchen-stuff Women? Has he weighed the ends of Candle, and Suet, to change for Candles of 20 in the pound?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: All this Sir, and he has been higling with a Fellow, above half an hour this morning, about 5 Coney-Skins he sold him; nay, Good man, he's very careful, and all for you.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: For me, • Sdeath I expect he should live fifty years longer, unless the Parliament would bring down money to four in the hundred; and faith I thought the report of that last Sessions, would have done an honest Filius ante Diem some kindness, but a pox ont he's recover'd, but no more of him, prethee send in my man to me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I will Sir Robin.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: What say you Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Go in to your Master [Ex. Robin] [Enter Theodora] Here comes the Mistress of my heart, my dearest Theodora, I see you now this morning, with as much Joy, as the Persians do the Rising Sun, that gives e'm all their Comfort.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: For all your complements Bellamour, I find little prospect of comfort for either of us.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My dearest Theodora, I have observed much dejection in your Countenance, ever since the obliging assurances you have given me of your faith; do you repent of that engagement? then I am miserable.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: No Bellamour, I cannot repent of any thing I do for you; you have too great a power overme, to suffer such resentments in my mind.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What then can be the reason, that in the miest of all my Joyes, I see you grieve.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: The thousand difficulties we are to undergo.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ah Madam, do but Love enough, and there are none.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: There is an impossibility of getting my Fathers consent, though it would be so much to my advantage: His covetous Shagrin Humour makes him hate a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have gained so much upon him, that I do not despaire of it; But since I have your consent, I have too much happiness for one man.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p:
I must confess, my Bellamour, I could justifie my Love to you to all the world, but to my Father; I have to defend me your Person, and your Merit: I can never repay the obligations I have received from you, that after seven years Travel, you can be content to stay from your Countrey, your Friends, and Kindred, and conceal your self from all the
world but me: But above all, to put your self for my sake, in so base a condition, as to serve my Father, which is worse than Rowing in Gallies, this Testimony of your Love can never be forgotten.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ah Madam! one kind look from you will overweigh a thousand such small Services: I must confess, serving your Father is the severest Task I have, to minister to his wretched Avarice, and endure the curses of all whom his extortion grieves. Pardon me, dear Theodora, that I take this liberty before you: This is a Subject, you know I can speak little good of.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I am too sensible of it, but I am extreamly glad to see you gain so much upon him by your Artifices.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You see Madam, Love is able to turne a man into all Shapes, nay into the worst, a Flatterer, to a Covetous man: But by the sordid applauding of what he does, and observing all his Rules and Maximes, I have gained this point; That he will hear or believe no man so soon as me.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: But why do you not discover this to my Brother, and procure his assistance in it?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your Father's and Brother's tempers are so opposite, that it is impossible to accommodate my selfe to both of 'em, but do you please to mannage our interests with your Brother, he Loves you extreamly, and will hear you; I hear him coming, I'le away.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Robin go stay within till I call you.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: I will Sir.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Dear Theodora I am glad you are here, I have a secret of the greatest concernment in the world to me, to discover to you.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: I shall be glad to hear't, and (if I can) to serve you in it; what have you to say?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: A thousand things, in one little word, Love.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: How Brother are you in Love, I'le tell you—

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Hold Sister, I know as well as you that I depend [Scommatically] upon a Father, and that the name of Son, carries an inviolable Duty along with it.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: But Brother—

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: And that I ought not to engage my heart without the consent of him who gave me breath.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Do you hear—

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: And that Heaven has made our Parents disposers of our wills, and that they are in a condition to see more and be less deceived than we.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Hold a little.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: And that we ought to trust the Eyes of their wisdom before the blindness of our own passion.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Are you mad—

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: And that the heat of our youth misleads, and betrays us often to dangerous precipices.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Not one of these wise things would I have said to you, but tell me, are you engaged to her you Love?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: No, but resolv'd, in spight of all opposition, and I conjure you, give me no reasons.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Why do you believe I will?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: You are no Lover, and faith I am damnably affraid of your wisdom.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: You know not my condition Brother; but pray who is it that has Charm'd you thus?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: A young Lady that Lyes near this place, of so excellent a Beauty, so delicate a creature, I cannot think of her without an extasie.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Pray save your oratory, and in short, tell me who she is.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Her name is Isabella; but that which is my extreamest trouble, I have discover'd under hand, that she is the Daughter of a sickly Widdow, and of a small Fortune: You know the abominable humour of my Father (whose damn'd covetousness, if I had not n • w and then a Lucky hand at play, would make me forget all use of money) so that I have scarce any possibility of giving this Lady the least proof of my affection; and if I find not some means to do it, I am lost.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: It is an inhumane thing of him to put us both to our Shifts, thus, to get but ordinary Cloths.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
Theodora.
sp.p: I hear him coming, he's inraged at something, pray let us retire and consult what to say to him, here he comes, step in.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Come on.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Out of my house you Dog, begon, make no replyes, you Rascal, that are a Sworn Thief; the Gallows groans for you.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Well, there was never any thing so wicked as this [Aside] damn'd old Fellow, and I think, under correction, the Devil's in him.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What's that you mutter between your Teeth Sarrah?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Why do you hunt me up and down thus?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Out you Hang-Dog, must you ask questions? Out of my Doors, or I'le knock you down.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: A pox on this damn'd flea-flint [Aside] Why what have I done to you?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Dispute no more, begon.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: My Master gave me order to stay here for him.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Get you gone and wait in the Street, you Rascal, must you stand here like a Sentinel, and (with your damn'd watchful Eyes) be a Spy upon my actions, to devour what I have, 〈◊〉 to ferret up and down to see what there is to Steal.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: What a Devil do you think I should steal, unless I should steal you? [Aside] Besides, He's as watchful as an Owl, a man that had killed seven men, Pissing against a wall, would rest more quietly.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You Dog must I be daily in danger to be Rob'd by you?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: You are not a man to be Rob'd, all you have is uner Lock and Key; besides you profess your self to be in great dant.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p:
[Aside] Oh how I tremble! Least this Rogue should suspect I have money hidden in my Garden: If he do's I am ruin'd. Though I have but little Sirra • , I should be loth to loose it by such Rascals as you are. Besides what's Lock't up, is not there
a Tin Candlestick, a Pair of Brass Snuffers, a Nutmeg-Grater, Bellows, and a Darnock Carpet.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: I scorne 'em all.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come Sirrah, you are one of the Rogues that reported that I have money hid.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: How, have you money hid say you?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No no you Dog, I don't say so, I have no money hid you Villain you. [Aside] 'Sdeath he distracts me.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Why what is't to me whether you have or have not.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What are you arguing? I'le beat your foolish reasons out of your head, once more, begon.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Well, I go.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Stay, have you taken nothing with you?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: You had best search me.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Shew me your hands.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: There.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The other—Both together—Stay have you put nothing here.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: What a Devil should I put there?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Let me see here.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Such a man as you deserves to be Rob'd.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What say you?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: I say I think you'l grope me all over.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: So I will Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: A Plague on all covetousness, and covetous men.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: I say, a Plague upon all covetousness, and covetous men.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Of whom do you speak Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Of covetous men.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What are those covetous men?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Rogues, Villans, Dogs, Caterpillers, Horse-Leeches, Vipers, Theives, Robbers, Sons of Whores.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How now you Rascal.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Why do you trouble your selfe Sir, you are none of those; may not I curse covetous Rogues?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Sirrah, to whom did you speak thus? tell me.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: I spoke it—I spoke it—to that Rogue Dives in the Picture there.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: And I speak to your fools head there, Sirrah take that, do you feele me Rogue?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Ay, pox on you, against my will.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Again Sirrah, out of my doors, I say, you insolent Villain.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: A curse on him, he has broken my bones.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh the pains, the Jealousies, and fears a man must suffer that has great summes of money to guard; I cannot find one place safe enough about the house; Coffers and Trunks Theives can never scape. Let me see this particular. Imprimis, a thousand Pound, for which I have Pawnes worth two, at above fifty per Cent. Item in the City five thousand Pound, for which I have ten per Cent, and the best security in England. [Enter Theodore and Theodora▪] Item in Morgages of Land from young Gay Sparks 6000l. Oh but that dear sum of six thousand broad pieces in my Garden, that transports me. [He sees his Son and Daughter.] 'Sdeath that I should read this Note loud, I have betrayed my self, they have over-heard me, and I am ruin'd; would they were both hang'd: Well, what's the matter with you, have you been long there?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: No Sir, but now come.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What do ye stand listening?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Not we, I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come come ye did: if they over-heard me, I shall hang my self—

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Not we, I assure you Sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I was saying to my self, how happy should I be if I had but six thousand Pound in the world.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: You need not wish that.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Tis false, 'tis false, Oh would to heaven I had! Oh how happy should I be, I should never complain then, that the times are hard, not I.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: This is all but Raillerie Sir.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: You have more than five times as much.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, what says he? Oh thou Villain, thou Viper thou, have I bred thee up to destroy me? are my Children become my greatest enemies?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Are those your enemies that say you are rich?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh it is the vilest injury you can do me, such discourses as these will make my throat be cut, Thieves will believe I am all made up of Gold; your extravagant expences too, will make 'em think so.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I know none I am guilty of, unless keeping my self clean be so.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh your Periwigs, your Ribbands, your Laces, you are as much a Spark as any of those that go fine, keep Whores, and pay no debts, about the Town; and if the truth were known, you, and your Sister, here, must Rob me to do it.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: He will have good luck that Robs you: [Aside] You know my Sister ventures some money at Sea, (that was left her by an Aunt,) and (for me) I am sometimes lucky at play, and I eat and drink, and keep my self handsomly drest with it.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Handsomly, foolishly; to what end are these multitudes of Ribbands, this Flaxen Mop of Whores Hair, and this Flanders Lace upon the Shirt; I warrant this Habit cost thirty Pound: now if you do win money, put it to other uses (you foolish young Knave) 30 l. comes to six and thirty shillings a year, according to Statutable use; But thou mightest make twenty Pound a year on't, if thou hadst any braines, and (with such use upon use) what would 30 l. come to in seven years!

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: But Sir, my Brother and I came to talke with you of other business.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Well, and I have something to say to you, of other business.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Tis concerning Marriage, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: And I intended to speak to you, concerning Marriage.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Ah Father!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Ah Father! what's that for? what? what? you would be at it already, would you? soft and fair young Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: No Sir, my Sister is affraid that your opinion of Marriage will not agree with ours.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Fear not, you shall have no cause of complaint, I shall do well for you both; and (first of all) have you Theodore, seen one Isabella, that lyes near this place?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: O yes Sir, several times, in her Balcony.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: And you?

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: I have heard of her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Well Son, and how do you find that Lady?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: She's admirably handsome, I have never seen her equal.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Her face, ha?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Beyond what e're a Lover fancied of his Mistress.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Her shape, is it not well?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Not only faultless, but excellent to a miracle.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Her meen, ha—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Graceful, and admirable.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Her ayer, and her manner—

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: The most charming in the world; her ayer so full of modesty and wit, her carriage so allureing and gentle, I have never seen the like.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh oh, would not this Lady make a pleasant bed-fellow?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: It were a happiness beyond all expression, such as 'twere not safe to think on't.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But there is one point to be consider'd, her Portion.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Oh Sir, that (with so fine a Lady) is not considerable, not to be mentioned.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Besides Sir, I have heard she has a tollerable fortune.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Never think of that.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Well, I am glad we agree so well in our opinions of this Lady; for (by these charming qualities) she has so won upon me, that I am resolved forthwith to marry her.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Oh heaven!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What say you?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Are you resolved say you—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes, to marry Isabella.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: Who you? you?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes I, I, I, why, what do you make of me, young Cox-comb?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: 'Sdeath this has struck me to the heart.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Who cares, go get some Aqua-Vitae, I hope this young Prodigal Ass will hang himself at the news of a young Mother-in-Law—This Daughter, is that which I resolve for my self: now for him, I have provided a grave Matron of about 50, with a great deal of money; and you, I intend to marry to Timothy Squeeze, the rich Scriveners Son, a very thrifty young man.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Heaven, what do I hear!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: He's a very pretty young man, and knowes how to make sixty per Cent of his money.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Sir, if you please, I will not marry.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Madam, if you please you shall marry.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Pray pardon me Sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Pray pardon me Madam.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: You may command me in any thing, but this.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I will command you in this, and to night too.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: To night, that shall not be.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: That shall be.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: I'le kill my self, before I marry him.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You shall not kill your self, and you shall marry him; but did ever Father endure such insolence from a Daughter?

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Was ever Daughter so severely used by a Father?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: All the world will allow of my choyce.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: No man of sense will.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Here comes Bellamour, will you be judg'd by him.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.l: With all my heart.
This is lucky enough.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Look you Bellamour, my Daughter disputes with me, which do you think has reason, she or I?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh Sir, you without question.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Do you know what we were talking of?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No Sir, but you cannot be in the wrong.

sp.speaker: Gold.
Bell.
sp.p: And am I to be Judge?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Ay of this.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh heaven!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What say you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am of your opinion Sir, in the main, but your Daughter is not wholly in the wrong.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why, why is Mr Timothy's Person, or Fortune, to be rejected? where can she have a better?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That's true Sir, but she may say, 'tis too rash to resolve to do it so suddenly; and that she ought to have some time to accommodate her inclinations to him.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Time, come I must take occasion by the fore-lock; his Father (that is very rich, but of mean extraction) will (for the sake of good Allyance) let his Son marry her without a Portion.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay then, I must say no more, that is a convincing reason, she must submit to that.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: What means Bellamour?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I know not what 'tis to her, I am sure 'tis the most confiderable reason in the world to me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Without doubt Sir, no man can contradict that, but your Daughter may answer you, that Marriage is the most solemn thing in the world, and that which must make her always either happy, or miserable.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Without Portion! mark that—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You have reason Sir, that decides all. But Sir, people will tell you, that the inclination of your Daughter, ought to be a little regarded; and that forcing affections has often ruined the best of Families.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What without Portion?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay, there can be no reply to that: 'tis true, there are a great many Fathers that prize the satisfaction of their Daughters, and would never Sacrifice them to interest, but would consult their affections.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But again I say, without Portion.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis true, without Portion is an answer to every thing; and who can resist such reason as vours.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: [To himself] Oh heaven I hear the Dog bark, I am so affraid of this money, I must into the Garden: stay here.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Bellamour you are in the wrong, to talk thus with him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If I should oppose him Madam, I should ruine our design, and you will do better to feign a consent to what he commands.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: But for this sudden Marriage, to night.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Wee'l find means to break it, and make him consent to it.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: What can you invent?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Feign some sickness, and desire him to delay't for that.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Physitians will find out that deceit.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Madam, he would scarce be at the charge of one to save his own life, much less yours.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: But he has Kindred, that will give him their advice for nothing.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Madam do you believe in Doctors? do you think they know more than Nurs-keepers? I warrant you Madam, counterfeit what distemper you please, they'l find reasons enough to tell you from whence it comes.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Heaven be praised, all's well, there was no body.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Besides Madam, our last recourse shall be to discover our selves, and our affections, and if you can be constant, as I doubt not— [Goldingham is seen by them.] Madam (as I was saying) a Daughter ought not to dispute her Fathers will, or once think whether she likes the man or no, whom he chuses for her; especially where that invincible reason, of without Portion, offers its self.

div.stage: [Theodora flings from him hastely, and goes out.]

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Well said Bellamour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, I ask you pardon, that I make so bold with your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I am orejoy'd at it, you have done exceeding well.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, I will never fail to urge her with arguments, and especially, that undeniable one, of without Portion.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Tis very well.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh Sir, there's nothing (in this world) so precious as money, not Honour, Birth, Education, Wit, Courage, Vertue, Wisdom, Religion, Loyalty—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh there spoke an Oracle! dear Bellamour I could hug thee for this, thou shalt follow, and advise her. But first, give me some little account of this days business, has Sarah the Orange-Wench redeem'd her Thumb-Ring, that I lent her ten shillings upon last week?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Tis forfeited then, it weighs two and twenty. Has the fellow that cryes old Cloths, redeem'd the new Velvit Coat (which I believe he Stole) or the Oyster-Woman her Red Petticoat with Silver Lace on't? or has the Cobler redeem'd his Pewter that he Pawn'd for money to buy Soles? or has the Country Gentlewoman (that lost her money at play) taken out her Watch, for which she is feign to make excuses to her Husband, and say 'tis a mending?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: None of these.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Has the Whetston Whore redeem'd her Mantoplicee, and her Silk-dy'd Petticoat, with Gold and Silver Lace?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No poor soul, she has had ill trading of late.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: There is a Bauds Silver Aqua-Vitae Bottie, a Midwife's hackny Satin Mantle, with old fashion'd Gold Lace; a Herald Painter's Hears-Cloth, and Velvit Pall; besides (let me see) an Attorneys Clerk Pawn'd a Beaver of his Masters in the Country; there is too, a Porters and a Water-mans Silver Badge, the Fidler's Violin, the Hackny Trumpeter's Brass Trumpet, the Barber's inlayd Razor Case, with Silver heads to his Instruments, are any of these redeem'd to day?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: None of 'em Sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p:
They are forfeited, to Hell with them, ab inferis nulla redemptio, this has been a happy week Bellamour: two young Sparks have forfeited Morgages this week: they are the sweetest people to deal with, they seldom fail of forfeiting
them, and I never fail to take 'em, but prethee go to my Daughter, and advise her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I will Sir,
Better then you think.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How happy am I in this servant! well, (if this trade holds) I shall tumble in money; and next to that.
sp.l: The greatest pleasure I can have of life,
Is in cold age, to have a warm young wife.

div.head: ACT. II.
SCE. II.

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: IS Mr. Goldingham at home?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: He is in the Garden (where he always is) I'le tell him you are here.

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: Come Timothy, Cheere up, has't not thou forgot to put on thy little Cuffs, to Comb thy head, and get thy hair powder'd.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: No no, I have my best Cloaths on too, just as I used to go to Church; but de' hear Sir, I shall be asham'd when Theodora comes, de' see, for (on my conscience and soul) I shall never learn how to Suitour a woman.

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: Take my directions, and I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: How did you go to work to Suiter my Mother?

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: Why, I'le tell thee, when I was a young man, (Oh the happy days we lived in then) I could woe a young Gentlewoman, with as much dexterity, as the Sprucest Gallant on 'em all.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I long to hear, before Mrs. Theodora comes.

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: Why look you, suppose thou wert thy Mother, stand there (and I'le tell you she was as fine a young Lass, as any Aldermans Daughter, (though she was but a Button-makers Daughter) and as well bred too; I am sure it cost her Father ten shillings a month for her learning to Dance, and she play'd most violently upon the Cittern too But stand still, thus I begun. [He Salutes, and Kisses Timothy.] Then forsooth your Servant, said I, wont you please to sit down? here's a Chair, and please you.

div.stage: [He sets a Chair for Timothy, and sits down by him.]

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I vow this is very well, de' conceive me?

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: Then thus I went on; pray give me leave to kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: O Lord Sir!

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: I protest and vow, I have a very great affection for you; the very thoughts of you, has often broke my sleep; and made me fetch many a sigh.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, very well I vow.

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: For you are very handsom (as I am an honest man, and I cannot but love you, an I were to be hang'd for't.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: 'Tis your goodness more than my desert.

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: Good lack, to see the luck on't, she made that very answer, I protest.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Oh Gemini, why did she?

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: Yes, but to go on, said I, I am come to see if you can love such a one as I am, (and I was then as pretty a young Fellow as any in the City) and if you can, said I, I shall be very well content to make you my wife.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay but Mrs. Theodora, they say, is most pestilent Coy.

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, be thou bold, and she'l not deny thee.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay and I will now you bid me, though I venture my life for't, de' understand me?

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: Do, stand up to her man, and kiss her, she'l not deny thee, for thou art a very pretty Fellow, though I say't; stand up, let me see, turn thee about, well made too, well thou takest just like me, I was just such another when I was young.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Mr. Squeeze you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: Thank you good Sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: And you Mr. Timothy.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Thank you good Sir, (as my Father said before me.)

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: This is the young man I bring to your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay Sir, I make bold to come a woing to Mrs. Theodora, de' conceive me, if your worship please.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: An excellent choice, an accomplisht, Rival have I: I should sooner be jealous of a Ballad-singer, or a Pick-pocket.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Bellamour, go call my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I will Sir, A curse on him, must she be baited by this Bandog.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: While the young people are together, wee'l drink a Cup; I would send for a Pint of white Wine, or half a Pint of Sack for you, but the Vintners do play the Rogues so, and put Horse-flesh, dead Dogs, mens bones, Molossus, Lime, Brimstone, Stumme, Allom, Sloes, and Arsnick into their Wine— but I'le send for a Cup of wholesome Ale for you.

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: There's the sweet youth, he has provided for you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Now Father stand by me.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: This Daughter, is the pretty young man I told you of.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: He looks more like a Corn-Cutter than a Lover.

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: Your servant young Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Your servant forsooth, I make bold to Salute you, de' see: I vow 'tis the sweetest kiss that ever I had in all my life; you kiss very well Mrs. Theodora, pray let me have another.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Hold Sir, not too fast.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Why look you Father, did I not tell you how 'twould be?

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: You were a little too forward Son.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come let's leave the young people, they'l do best together.

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: Ay I warrant you, they had rather be alone.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: D'y' hear Theodora, be civil to him Bellamour!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: So now we are alone Mrs Thea, I call you Thea for shortness, de' see? will you please to sit down?
Il'e try now if I can out-do my Father.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.l: To wait upon you I will Sir.
What a ridiculous Lover have I?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Come Mrs. Thea, I profess my Legs are very weary, I have been all this morning dunning for money, at this end of the Town; and I promise you I mind my business as well as e're a young man in the City that wears a head,, but (a deus take 'em) they do so fob me off with Protections hereabouts.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: They do ill, to disappoint so fine a Person.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ah forsooth, you are pleased to say so, but come (now I think on't) pray where's your Maid?

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Why do you ask?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: If you please to send her to some Tavern, where you have Credit, I'de make bold to send for a Pint of Sack for you, (there I out-do my Father a whole half Pint.)

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.l: Oh admirable breeding.
By no means I don't love it, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Then I'le send for a Bottle of white Wine; I have Sugar in my pocket, the Rogues at Tavern's make us pay three pence a paper for it.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: A thrifty consideration, but I drink no Wine.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nay peuh Mrs Thea, you say this now to save me Charges, de' see; but alas I care no more for money than I do for the dirt under my foot, d' you understand me? if I had you at the Pope's Head, I'de give you half a peck of Oysters, I have as good Credit there as ere an Alderman's Son of 'em all, no dispraise: but faith I will send for White-Wine now, you shall not say me nay.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Oh intollerable! I will have none sent for.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Sir, your Father bids me tell you he is sent for to Chatolins, to some young Blades, whom he is to take up

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: 'Tis very well. Come Mrs Thea, pray be not angry, but let us to our business.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Have you any with me?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Yes that I have, and very earnest business too, I'le tell you that.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Look you Mrs. Thea, pauca verba, the short and the loug on't is, I have had a very great affection for you, any time these two months, ever since I saw you at Covengarden Church, de' conceive me?

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Oh wonderful!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: As I am an honest man, you have stuck as close to my heart (all the time,) as a Burr (de' understand me) nay I have scarce slept a quiet night, all that time, for dreaming on you.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nay feck now 'tis true, whereupon my Father seeing me in this condition, advised me to come to you for cure, de' hear me?

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Oh Sir, doubt not but you may command me.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: No forsooth pardon me, I shall intreat you.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: To do what?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Feck only to love me a little, that's all.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: No more but that! how can I chuse?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay but will you have me for a husband, de' see? that's the business I come about: if you will, I shall for my part, be very glad to make you my Bed-Fellow, as the saying is.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Oh Sir, you deserve one of a greater Beauty and Fortune than I am.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Pshaw what's matter for that, 'tis all one as long as my Father bid me ask you Mrs. Thea, de' conceive me?

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Sure this Holiday Fool, ha's never been bred to any thing but throwing at Cocks, or demolishing evil houses on Shrove-Tuesday; or may be, he ha's Rid on a Pageant for a Neptune, or a Sea-god, or perhaps waited at my Lord Mayor's Table upon a Feast day.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What say you to the proposition, ha?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Did you see your Brother Madam?

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: He's gone out.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: A deus take this Fellow for interrupting us.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Within. Theodora.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Heark, I am call'd, farewell.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nay an I leave you, the King shall know it.

div.stage: [Enter at the other Doors Mrs. Cheatly.]

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Oh dear Robin, art thou here?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Mrs. Cheatly, what makes you here for heavens sake?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: That which makes me go every where; I love to be serviceable to the Nation, in my faculty, I bring people together, and make work for the Parsons, and the Wid-wifes. But where's Mr. Goldingham.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: What business can you have with him? of all mankind.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: That which I hope to get by; you know I have no Rents, Industry, and Intrigue must maintain me; but thou art sure not to lose by it, my dear Robin.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: And you not to get by it here, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: You don't know, there are some things within my power, that may touch very nearly.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Why thou mayst sooner hope to get by thy Trade in a Town three years besieged, and almost famished.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I warrant you, I have a way of tickling of 'em as they do Trouts out of their senses, but I must work upon him by degrees.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Why he would not give a shilling to save thy soul, nor eighteen pence for his own; I have heard him wish that that word Give, were blotted out of the English Tongue: you'l put him into Fits, if you but propound it to him. 'Slife here he comes, I must be gone I am sure.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Ah dear Sir, how briskly you look to day, good lack! If I had not been in your house, I protest I should not have known you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I look well, alas, alas!

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I never saw any creature so chang'd in my life, sure you drink nothing but Viper Wine.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Nay you wheadle.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Upon my life, you amaze me, you look so delicately, so fresh, and gay.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Nay but do I? hah.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Sir, you were never so young in your life, I have seen men of five and twenty in white Periwigs, have less youth about them.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But (for all that) I am above six and fifty.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Six and fifty! alas that's nothing, that's the season of a perfect man, you are now in the flower of your Age— it was the time when the Patriarchs you know began to get Children.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: That's true, but if I were twenty years younger, 'twould do me no hurt.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: You jest Sir, you need no youth, I'le lay my life you will live till you are a hundred years old.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No no, but do you think so really?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Most certainly Sir, you have all the markes of long life; let me see, hold a little: Oh what a sign of life there is upon your forhead! I am sure you'l have four wives more.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: —I care not how many wives I have, I love to bury wives much. [Aside.] But have you such skill in these things?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Ay as much as e're an Almanack-maker, or Cunning-man of 'em all; let me see your hand, Heaven! what a Line of life is here.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How, let me see.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Do you not see how farr that Line goes?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes, but what does that import?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: A hundred did I say? if you don't live to sixscore, I'le be content to be hang'd, when I am so old my self.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: You will live to bury all your Children, Grand-Children, Great-grand-children, and Posterity, to the fift and sixt Generation.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The more I bury, the better; what care I for Posterity, I would be my self the last man of my family.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Yes Sir, as you are the first.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But pray Mrs. Cheatly, how goes our affair?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: If it did not go extreamly well, you would not have me in so good a humour. Well on my conscience no woman in England ha's that faculty in Match-making, that I have: there are no two persons, so opposite, that I cannot bring together: (if I had liv'd in that time) I would have been hang'd if I had not Married the Pope to Queen Elizabeth.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But I would not have had that done, that might have spoyl'd the reformation: but tell me?—

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Why Sir? I acquainted the Mother with your proposition, and brought Isabella to the window (as you appointed,) where she survey'd your person, your age, your youth, I mean, your meen and all your motions.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: And how lik'd she, ha?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: She likes your person infinitely, and her Mother, and she entertained the proposal with a great deal of joy; and Isabella says you are the most Reverend charming old young Gentleman, in all Covengarden.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Tis her goodness, but in troth that was a little too much: but have you spoke with her Mother about Portion?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Oh shee'l be a vast Fortune, she will be worth above two thousand Pound a year to you (besides her Beauty) which if you would, you might make as much more of, if she would consent.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: And (if I can make so much more of her) I am sure I'le make her consent, or I'le strangle her. [Aside.] But how will she be worth so much besides?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Why first, she ha's the most thrifty Stomach of any woman in Europe; she loves nothing but Sallads, Milk, Cheese, Butter, and Apples, nor does she ever desire sweet meats above Almonds, and Raysins, you need not keep a table furnished with varieties, or delicacies for her: Wine she drinks none, this will be worth a thousand Pound a year; then she hates all finery, Lace she detests out of hatred to the French.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: She does well, it was a Roguish invention, and he that first invented it, is damn'd.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p:
She hates rich Cabinets, Pictures, rich furnished Clos • ets, and costly furniture extreamly, this (with her own thrift in Habits) will amount to above six thousand Pounds;
then she has a horrible aversion for Gaming, then Playes she detests.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: This is admirable, I am each minute more in love with her.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Then she never gives a farthing to the poor, though she sees 'em starving.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How admirably shall we agree, for I hate the poor as much as she can do.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Then she abominates Singing-Masters, French-Masters, Dancing-Masters, Harpsical-Masters, above measure; now to sum up all these things they will amount to 2450 l. a year, for her life, there's four hundred and fifty Pound above your sum.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Mrs. Cheatly, these things are very good, but they are not real goods, I would have something that I might give an Acquittance for, and say, I say Received per me Humphrey Goldingham.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Are not all these excellent qualities real Goods? and I assure you, you may receive them when you please.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: These are not Goods and Chattels Mrs. Cheatly; I must touch somthing.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Touch! why, you shall touch her, and touch her all over, and as much as you please, there's a delicate creature to touch, there's a touch for you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Ay, but I must touch money; there's a delicate thing to touch, there's a touch for you.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Money you shall have too, they have a good Estate in the North, which I have heard them speak of—

sp.speaker: Gold.
Cheat.
sp.p: Cods me I had like to have forgot that quality of hers, she has the most unconquerable aversion, in the world, for all young men; she was to have been Married t'other day, and broke off the match, because she found the man was not above fifty.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: It cannot be, sure.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p:
Upon my word 'tis true, she says the young men of this age, are nothing but brisk, airy, conceited, gay, proud,
ignorant, foolish, singing, dancing, Baboones in huge Periwigs, not fit for wives.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: It is impossible.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: If you did but see her Seals, and the few Pictures she ha's, not of Adonis, Paris, Apollo, Narcissus, or any young Figures, but of Saturne, King Priam, Anchises, Nestor, Methusalem, and some of the old Partiarchs, Iohn of the times, and old Parre.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: This is incomparable indeed, if I were a young woman I should never endure young Fellows; for my part I wonder what they can see in them, to love 'em so.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Ay I wonder what pleasure they can take in 'em, Oh yur fine old man for my money, he's the civilest, quietest Bed-fellow; worth a thousand of these young Fops, that are ever upon the spur, like a Citizen on a Journey.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Tis your goodness: But canst thou not bring this Isabella to Supper, to night, to my house? I am to give Mr. Squeeze, and his Son a Supper; who shall marry my Daughter immediately, and (if you can bring this Lady) I would kill two Birds with one stone, as that excellent thrifty Proverb says.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Ne're doubt it Sir, I'le bring her after Dinner to see your Daughter, and they may take the ayr in your Coach together, and so come back to Supper.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Prethee go about it instantly.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: But Sir—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Nay prethee Mrs. Cheatly go about it, make no delays, prethee go now—

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: One word more.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No more for heaven sake, go now.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I must speak to you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: By no means, go just now about it, now, go quickly.

div.stage: [He thrusts her on towards the door.]

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Well, there is nothing to be done with this old Fellow now.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p:
This Cheatly is a rare woman, but I was plaguily affraid she would have asked to borrow money of me, after she had done her story. 'Sdeath what do I hear! the Garden
door opens, she's gone in there; I must watch her, and my dear dear money.

div.stage: [Enter Bellamour and Theodora, as Gold. is going out.]

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: What, makes my Father in such hast? I believe he is gone into the Garden; where he goes a hundred times a day: But pray Bellamour, is your man returned, you sent into the North to enquire of your Father?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Madam I expect him to night. But my dearest Theodora, since I have your heart, there's nothing else I have within my eye, or thought! let us not think of business, but imploy this happy minute in talking of love.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Here's my Father, to your advice again.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: So all's safe in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Madam you must obey, and marry him to night, your Father will not delay the making of you happy.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: To night, is too sudden Bellamour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis never too soon to obey your Father Madam.

sp.speaker: Gold.
Theodora.
sp.p: Let me beg you will defer it Sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I will have it despatch'd to night, come along.

div.stage: [Rant, Hazard, Lettice, and Ioyce at Chatolins]

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: That Theodore should be such a Villain, to disappoint us.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: I wonder he should have no more care of his own soul, than to break his word with honest Fellows.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: I believe he knows of my being here; and has not the face to see me (after some inconstancy, I have taken him in lately.)

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: That she should pretend to an interest in him, Mr. Rant! but if every body that has injoyd her should be constant to her, (as she calls it) she would have an Army of Lovers.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p:
God-a-mercy Mrs. Ioyce, I'le drink thy health for that; here boy give me a Glass. [Boy gives a little Glass.] A pox on this thimble, give me such a Glass as your Nonconforming
Parson drinks in, after labouring at a Conventicle; as big as King Iohns Cup at Lyn, or Iohn Calvins at Geneva: That is fit for nothing but to wear in a mans Bandstring (as your Citizens do Rings.)

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Here's one will fit you Sir.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Fill it, and strike it.

sp.speaker: Lettice
sp.p: Here's thy health in a brimmer, Hazard have at thee.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: I'le do thee reason, dear Rogue, an 'twere a Pulpit full of Burgundy; I love such honest Fellows, that let drinking and wenching go hand in hand.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Faith they are such sweet sociable sinnes, 'tis pitty they should ever be parted.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Come boy, my Glass.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: But where's the Fiddlers you promised us?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.l: Here's Captain Theodore.
They cannot be farr off.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: How now Gentlemen, what so forward already? Ladies your servant.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: You see Theodore we are not wanting, we provide you good Company; but I am sorry you came not to Dinner.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: You see Mr. Theodore what I venture for your company; to undergo the Scandal of these Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: No Scandal I hope Mrs. Lettice! for women of your Tribe (like Fanaticks) are above Ordinances.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Mr. Theodore, you are very unkind of late, one can never see you: But you see I can venture to be ruin'd with my Alderman to see you; but not a word of this.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Fear it not, I am as much affraid of the Scandal as you are.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Come Theodore, thou wantest two or three Beer-Glasses; Is it not better to drink, and be free with these glorious Harlots, than to crouch to a foolish simpering Lady that's honest?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Thou art like a dry-foot-Dog, that (out of a whole Heard of Deer) singles out one, whose sent he only followes, and tires himself to catch that, when he might have twenty in the mean time.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Gentlemen! the Devil is much obliged to you, you are his great Champions; and defend Whoreing with as good arguments as any of his controversial Divines about the Town: But all this will not make me think ill of an honest woman.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: I tell you there is not a woman in the world, that's honest at all times, and upon all occasions.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: What not thy Mother, or thy Sister?

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: No gad, if they were, I would disown them, they had none of my blood in 'em.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Theodore let me advise thee not to speak contemptibly of Sons of Punks, for (if thou dost) Gad thou wilt raise a world of enemies.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I'le assure you, I have a better opinion of the Sex than what ill company, and your leud lives, have given you.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Ay pox on't, thou art not compos mentis, thou art in love; but here's a couple of remedies for that Disease; which (if thou dost not nip in the bud) will prove more dangerous than three Claps.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: I hope it's nothing but some fumes of the Spleen, that make him base company (for the present:) I hope (with these Ladies assistance) and a Bottle or two of Burgundy, to set them right yet.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: I am Mr. Theodore's humble servant, he shall want no assistance I can give him.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Nor will I be deficient in any thing to serve him.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Alas Madam, he does not ask your service, nor would it do him much good.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Goodlack Mrs. Lettice, you are so exalted by the bounty of Mr. Squeeze the Scrivener, and twenty or thirty more, that (unknown to him) Club with him.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Twenty or thirty, thou insolent creature; did you learn no better manners of your Alderman?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Hold Ladies, here are the Fiddlers. [Flourish of Fiddles.] Let them reconcile your quarrel. Come in youths.

div.stage: [Enter Fiddles.] [Enter Mrs. Cheatly and Mrs. Betty.]

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen you shall not be merry without me, I will participate.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Who is this thou hast brought with thee Mrs. Cheatly?

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: A pretty young Girle, which I am to marry to an old Prebend; but mum for that.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Boy give me a mighty Glass of Burgundy: Theodore here's thy Mistress's health; Hazard, to you, Fidlers play a health.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: You are very brisk, but I shall tame you, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Come Ladies, faith you shall not scape, wee'l warm ye first with Wine, and then with a Dance; Mrs. Cheatly.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: I'le pledge you Sir, but with allowance

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: With all my heart, take your liberty.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Mrs. Ioyce, Mr. Theodore's Mistress.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: With all my heart Madam Cheatly. [They Flourish.] There's one in this Room, perhaps is as nearly con cerned in it, as any body.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: For all that you know Mrs. Ioyce, I vow Mr. Theodore, her confidence makes me asham'd of her.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Alas poor modesty, fa la la.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: If you will have any singing, I'le sing you a little Countrey Song shall stirr up these Girles more than your Fiddles and Voyces can do.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Prethee do Cheatly.

lg.l: AS I walk'd in the woods one evening of late,
A Lass was deploring her hapless estate,
She sigh'd, and she sob'd, Ah wretched she said;
Will no youth come succour a languishing Maid?
Shall I still sigh and cry, and look pale and wan,
And languish for ever for want of a man?
At first when I saw a young man in the place,
My colour would fade, and then flush in my face,
My breath would grow short, and I shiver'd all o're;
I thought 'twas an Ague, but Alas it was more,
For e're since I've sigh'd, and do what I can,
I find I must languish for want of a man.
When in bed all the night I weep on my Pillow,
To see others happy, while I wear the Willow;
I revenge my selfe on the innocent sheet,
Where in rage I have oftentimes made my Teeth meet:
But all this won't serve, let me do what I can,
I find I must languish for want of a man.
Now all my fresh colour deserted my face,
And let a pale greenness succeed in the place,
I pine and grow faint, and refuse all my meat,
And nothing but Chalk, Lime, or Oatmeal, can eat:
But in my despair I'le die if I can,
And languish no longer for want of a man.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Really Madam Cheatly 'tis a pretty Song.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: 'Tis a little too wanton, that's the fault on't.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Nay, it cannot be too much of that; how dost like it Theodore?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Pox on't, there's no Wit in't.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Don't all your greatest Wits make Songs without any Wit at all in 'em, that take extreamly?

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Come Theodore take out they woman; wee'l bounce their bodies in a Dance.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Is Robin here? he Dances well, (with his Master's leave) he shall be my partner.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: With all my heart, but what news Robin?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Mr. Squeeze the Scrivener Sir will come to you, and bring the Gentleman that will lend the money.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Squeeze does not know me.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: No Sir, I told him it was a young Gentleman in whom he must be satisfied, when he knew his name.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Come Theodore, I bar all business now.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen I'le be as Idle for a while as the best of you, strike up.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Gentlemen by your leave, is my Farher here among ye?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Pox of this Rascal, knock him on the head.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Hold Rant, who is your Father?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Mr. Squeeze the Scrivener, de' understand me? Lord! that Gentleman needed not have been so angry, my Father is a Livery-man, de' see, I am no such contemptible person, I promise you.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Be civil to him, he has the Countenance of an excellent Buble.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: I warrant thee, I'le make much of him; Sir I hope you'l forgive my ignorance of your person; had I known you, I should not have been so unmannerly.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nay, 'las I'le be friends with you, for my part with all my heart; but my Father was sent for to this house, to some Gallants that wanted money: and by the noise and Ranting you kept here, de' understand me, I thought you had been the men.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: We expect him here every minute.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Now will you brace of Knaves Cheat this fool.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: If he scapes us one way or other, I'le forswear Caterdeus-ace, and smooth Box, as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Heaven! if Mr. Squeeze finds me here I shall be ruin'd for ever.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: Pray lets withdraw into another Room more private.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Go all into another Room, and I'le come to you suddenly; I will but speak one word with my man.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Come on Ladies: Come Sir we must engage you till your Father comes.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sir your servant, I don't care if I spend my Pint with you; and it be a Quart, I have money enough, de' see?

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: And shall have little enough, de' see, before we leave you.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Come Robin, is there any hopes of procuring the three hundred Pound?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Yes Sir, you may have the money upon some few conditions; and I (seeing you could not have it upon other termes) told him you must have the money upon any condition.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: So I must, but what are they?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: I'le read 'em to you Sir, I have 'em here in writing; first, you must engage some reversion of Land for security.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: That's reasonable.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Item Mr. Squeeze will have 30 l. for Broakerage, for he but procures it.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Oh damn'd Iew!

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Have patience Sir, you shall hear more: Item the Gentleman that Lends it, will not in conscience take above 6 in the hundred; but he will have a Present of 30 l. for a pair of Candlesticks.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: What cursed exaction's this!

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Item he will have you take the greatest part of it in Goods.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: A curse on him, what Moor or wild Arab is this?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Hold Sir, Imprimis a fine new Razor-Case, with Razors, and every thing suitable; the Case in-layd with Silver, and all the Instruments with Silver Heads, very fit for your man to learn to shave by.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Death and Hell! what's this?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Item A Bolonia Lute, a Roman-Arch Lute, 2 Gittars, a Cremona Violin, 1 Lyra Viol, 1 Viol de Gambo and a Trump-Marin, very fit for you, if you be a lover of Musick; Item a very neat Chess-Board, and a pair of Tables, very good to pass away the time with.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: What abominable Villains are these?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Item 15 large Pewter Dishes, 2 Dozen of Pewter Plates, two Brass Pots and a Kettle, very useful for you against you keep house. Item a Furnace of Brick, with the Cornues, and Recipients, very fit for you, if you be curious in Distilling. Item 1 Scru'd Pistol, 3 Muskets, 1 Back, Brest, Head-Piece and Gauntlet, and 5 Swords; these things are valu'd at 160 l.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: What Inhuman bloody Rogues are these? I should not have above 80 l. of all this money: Heaven what shall I do! money I must, and will have; though by all the extremities in the world.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But do you think there is no danger?

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: None at all, he says his Father is so well known, that no man will question him: Besides he is so pressed for money, that hee'l undergo what ever you can put upon him.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: That's very well.

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: Besides, hee'l go to the ensurance Office, and ensure his own life and his Fathers death, as you know they will ensure any thing.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: That's well again.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: 'Sdeath who's here, my Father? I am betrayd by this Rogue.

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: Oh Sir, your servant, this is the young Gentleman Mr. Goldingham that wants the money.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh Heaven, my Son! I am amaz'd.

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: Is it his Son? this is lucky, above my wishes, [Aside.] he will disinherit him; and my Son will have a Portion then, a large one with his Daughter.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: You Rascal, did you betray me? I'le cut your throat you Dog.

sp.speaker: Sque.
sp.p: I betray you! heaven forbid it.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh you Villain, is it you that abandon your self to these wicked extremities?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Is it you Sir that are guilty of these abominable extortions?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Is it you that would ruin your self by your debauchery? and borrow money upon such conditions?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Is it you Sir that seek to enrich your self by the Ruin of people, in lending money upon such shameful conditions?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Dare you appear before me after this?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Dare you appear before the world after this?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Have you no shame in you, you debauched Villain! to spend thus impiously, what I have sweat for; to make away the reversion of your Estate, upon such dishonorable conditions?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p:
Do not you blush to dishonour your Name, and
Family, by the most cruel exaction, and unheard of subtleties, that the most infamous of Usurers, nay Iews themselves could ne're invent.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Are you such a borrower?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Are you such a lender?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come along Mr. Squeeze, I cannot endure the sight of this Villain any longer.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: So, my affairs are in a very good posture, I am disappointed of money, and undone with my Father, if I cannot find out a way to bring my selfe off.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Make him believe, that it was for another you inquired for the money; and knowing that Squeeze dealt with your Father (which I am sure you ne're suspected till now) that you intended it for your Father's advantage.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Wee'l think on't, and for Squeeze, I hope my friends in the next Room will Revenge me to the full upon his Son; I'le into 'em, and set them on'.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Do Sir, and at misfortunes ne're repine,
While there are handsom Women and good Wine.

div.head: ACT. III.
SCE. III.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: SIR, I have at length broke loose by force from my Company, to wait on you; my Sister has told the honour you have done her, and me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Sir I humbly beg your pardon for not first making my address to you: My long absence had made me a stranger to all the Town, and by that means to your Character; had
I known you to be a man of that honour I find you, I should not have gone so indirect a way.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Sir I am happy that (any way) this favour can be conferred by a person of your worth upon my Sister; and so much honour on my selfe; and therefore 'tis my interest, as well as inclination, to desire of you that all Names may be layd by between us too, but that of Brother.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It is a Name that since you are pleased to honour me with it, shall not be forgotten, or ungratefully own'd while I live.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Dear Brother, let me embrace you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Let this eternally bind us, my dearest Brother.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I am extreamly glad you have prevailed so upon my Fathers opinion, since it may be of great use, as well to your own affairs, as to mine.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do not distinguish our interests, for yours is now become mine.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I am extreamly oblig'd to you for your kindness, and I have now occasion to use you in a business of my own; I know you will excuse my freedom.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: There's nothing you can ever do to me, can need an excuse; nor is there any thing you can ask of me, which I can deny.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I doubt not but my Father has e're this told you of his anger against me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He has, and I am very sorry for it, but I hope to serve you in this affair.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I can put you in a way to do it, as thus, I'le tell you immediately.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Oh Mr. Theodore, your friends are very angry with you for leaving of 'em; but you Coxcomb young Squeeze is as drunk as a Bully, and so sweet upon Mrs. Ioyce (who is the only woman I have left with them) that there is no staving him off her: She perswaded him to play with Hazard at Backgammon, and he ha's already lost his Edward shillings that he kept for Shovel-board, and was pulling out broad pieces (that have not seen the Sun these many years) when I came away.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I am heartily glad on't, I am sure the Rogues have no more mercy than a Bayliff with an execution in his pocket; but prethee what brings you hither? does my Father go astray towards the flesh?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: No no, I come to borrow money of him upon Security; good enough, as you shall find to your cost.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I'le send him to you, come my dear Brother.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I wait on you.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: If I be not reveng'd of Theodore, for using my Daughter unkindly, I have lost my cunning; I am sure there can be no Instrument of it so certain, as a Mother-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: —Dear Mrs. Cheatly! were not you discourag'd enough last time, but you must venture again hither?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: I'le never give him over till I prevail upon him.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: It is impossible, you'l sooner perswade a profest Iew to Swines flesh and Images, than him to parting with money.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
