sp.p: Distrust not my art.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: I heartily wish it might prevail, though I despaire on't, for (to say truth) Mrs. Cheatly I have need at present for a great deal of love, not forgetting a little money, from you.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Thou shalt want neither, as long as I can help thee; here's somthing, come to my house at night, and thou shalt have more.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Thank you dear Mistriss, it comes seasonably— Though loving such a one as she deserves very well; yet this is the freest Titt that ever had inclination to mankind.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: S'death you Rogue, are you about my house? begon Rascal.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Call me Rascal before my Mistriss? I could find in my honour to beat him for an old Sink-cater.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Why do you use Robin so unkindly? he's a pretty ingenious young man.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hang him Rascal! But prethee how goes our business on?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p:
As you can wish: she says she sawy ou even now
walk under her Window, and made me the pleasantest description, and is so taken with you! She says you are of a fit Age and Beard for her, and infinitely admires the Gravity and Decency of your Habit

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Does she like me, say you?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: To admiration: Pray Sir turn you; just that delicate shape, that convenient height that she describ'd! Pray let me see you walk: just that free and janty meen, that very easie and unconstrained motion which she describ'd.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: It is strange she should take so much notice of me in so short a time, hah.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: She says you look as if you had no kind of infirmity.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I have none very great, (thank heaven) I have only a defluction that troubles me sometimes.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
Gold.
sp.p: No no, you jest, you are a wag; but will Isabella come to see my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I am to go and wait on her hither immediately.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Cheatly you oblige me infinitly.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: I oblige her of all things in the world. [He Smiles.] But Sir, I have an humble Petition to you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What the Devil says she?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: I am just now at the point of being cast in a Suit, for want of a little money to Fee my Lawyers with; you may if you please easily supply me, you cannot [He Smiles.] imagine what joy she had when I told her I would wait on her to your house; you cannot believe what pleasure shee'l have to see you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Me, alas! alas!

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p:
Upon my word Sir, this Suit is of that consequence to me, that I shall be ruin'd, if I lose it; [He Frownes.] and a little assistance from you will restore my business again; Oh! if you could but have seen what [He Smiles again.] transport she was in, when I was speaking of you, what joy
shin'd through her eyes, when I repeated your excellent qualities to her: in fine, I have made her very impatient till this Marriage be concluded.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You have done me the greatest pleasure imaginable, and I owe all the kindness in the world to you.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Sir since it is so, I beg of you that you will afford me the small supply which I demand.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Well, adieu, I'le go see all things prepar'd for her reception in time.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: I assure you, you could never supply me in so great an exigence.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Well, I'le see my Coach and Horses put in order, for ye to take the air.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: I should not importune you, if I had not the greatest necessity in the world.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Let me know what she and you love best, that I may bespeak it to Supper.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: I beg of you, do not refuse me; you cannot imagine the pleasure a little sum of money would do me.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Well, I must go see that Supper be ready in good time, for fear ye should be sick, if ye eat too late.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Pray consider my condition—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I warrant ye you shall have Supper ready early enough, I'le bespeak it instantly: Farewel.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: This is the most obdurate, inhuman old Fellow; that are yet ventur'd a soul to the Devil for money.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: What, you have succeeded just as I expected.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: A curse on him, he was prepar'd and fortified against all my Attaques

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: I tell you, you will sooner perswade Quakers to conform, and wear the Surplice; or Bauds to become Nuns; than him to part with any money.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
Robin.
sp.p:
This Trafficking for Maiden-Heads is an exc • llent
Profession; but they are very dear, for their Rarity.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: But I think I must wholly leave of Trading about Marriages, the Market runs higher at present t'other way.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Faith then, its the wisest course.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: I'le consider on't, but come you shall usher me to the Lady I speak of.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Allons.

div.stage: Hazard, Rant, Timothy, Ioyce, Boy Tim. and Haz. at Tables.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: On my conscience and soul you Cog, de' see? look on the Motto o'th' Tables, Play fair and swear not, de' hear me?

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: On my honour Sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: A Devil take your honour for me, de' see? that's all your word at this end of the Town; de' conceive me? but for all that, one can't trust a man of ye: Here it goes Size-ace, Hazard hold out.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Did ever man see the like! on my conscience and soul you deal with the Devil, de' mark me? Mrs. Ioyce, let me have but one kiss, de' conceive me, and I shall win the Game fack.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Nay fie Mr. Timothy.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nay ne're offer to resist, de' see? for would I might ne're stir if I han't it, if I set upon't; Come Come.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: You are but a rude person, let me tell you that.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I told you I'de have it, I faith; now Sir I am for you.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Prethee Ioyce be not so coy to this young Fool, he may be of great advantage to us all, and especially to thee.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: I hope he might use more Courtship to a person of my quality, there is some difference sure.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Prethee let there be none, I am sure you will not repent it. Mr. Timothy, here's the Ladies health in a brimmer.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I'le pledge you an't were a Peck (six and three) for would I might ne're go home alive if she be not one of the Prettiest Gentlewomen I ever saw in my life (Sink-Duce) Come drink it off.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: 'Tis off, and there's a brimmer for you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Where are the Fiddles? I'le vow and swear I will not drink without Fiddles.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: They are drinking in the next Room, Boy, call 'em in.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Twelve, there's, a Back-Gammon, the Gold is my own.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: A duce tak't, I have lost all, as I am an honest man, on my conscience you have made a League; I make no more of Mr. Selware's Journey-man next Door to us, I give him one in five.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: If you want any money, you shall have what you will of mee; but drink the health first.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Come on, Musicianers, strike up, Hey: Here forsooth, here's your health; and would I might ne're go out of this place, if I would not drink it sooner than my Sisters, or my Mothers, if she were alive: Ha ha, [He drinks, they Flourish.] this is the Prettiest way of drinking I vow; it incourages us, as Drums and Trumpets do, when we let off our Guns at a Muster. Come Hey, what care I for losses, my Father ha's money enough, de' see? Mrs. Ioyce, with your Cozens leave, I make bold to love you with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: I am oblig'd to you really, but I know not how to return it.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: O your love! I warrant you, you know well enough if you would; well to morrow we show at Hide-Park, and (if I know your Lodging) I'le give you a Gun as I come back, and steal a Bottle of Sack, and the Tip of a Neats-Tongue, and bring you, I tell you that.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Nay prethee Hazard give an honest account, don't sink for shame.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Upon my honour; he lost no more, what dost take me for a Cheat?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen you don't drink, give me a Glass, here's my Mistriss's health; I make bold to call you so, de' see?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: O your servant.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Come Gentlemen, an't I pure Company now? strike
up Musicianers, Hey; Gad you think we Citizens are [He drinks.] Good for nothing, de' conceive me? but there's a knot of us, of about sixteen or eighteen, if we get together, can be as merry, as the best of you; we can i faith, and sing, a Boat, a Boat, or herer's a health to his Majesty, with a fa la la la lero; and Roar gallantly Mrs. Ioyce.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Methinks you are as Pretty a Spark as any about the Town.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I think so fack, I'le scorn any of 'em should out-do me if I set upon it. Hey!

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: What, have you hurt your self?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: 'Pshaw, not at all, fa la la lero, come [He Sings.] Mrs. Ioyce, wee'l have a Song faik now; Violin men, (I dare not call 'em Fiddlers, for fear they should be angry) sing us a Catch; Oh I have seen one of these Act the Countrey man, and Simkin in the Chest rarely; and you may talk of your Playes, but give me such Pretty harmless Drolls for my money.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Well, you are a merry man.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I'le be as merry as the best, hang losses, Hey, Hey, strike up, fa la la la la lero.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Let me embrace you, dear Mr. Timothy; well he's admirable company Mrs. Ioyce.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Oh! am I so? Sing a Catch you Rogues, or I'le break your heads; give me a Glass; here Adversary, here's to you.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: A pox on him, hee'l be too drunk.

lg.head: A Catch in four parts.
lg.l: Come lay by your cares, and hang up your sorrow,
Drink on, he's a Sot, that er'e thinks on to morrow;
Good store of good Claret supplies every thing,
And the man that is drunk, is as great as a King.
Let none at misfortunes, or losses repine,
But take a full Dose of the juice of the Vine;
Diseases and troubles are ne're to be found,
But in the damn'd place, where the Glass goes not round.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: An admirable Song Mrs. Ioyce, thank you honest friends: I have heard these men sing gallantly before my Lord Mayor; Diseases and Troubles are ne're, &c.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Come will you take Revenge on Hazard, here's twenty Pound if you will.

sp.speaker: Tim.
Rant.
sp.p: Is not that good news Hazard?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Come Mrs. Ioyce lets sing and be merry a bitt; Diseases and Troubles, &c. Hey. [He falls down dead drunk.] Mrs. Ioyce come to Bed: Come I say quickly, I am in hast, come away.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: So now you have done well, this Rogue has 20. l. about him; and you have made him so drunk, he cannot lose it to us.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Lets carry him into another Room to sleep, and pick his Pocket; gad it's all one.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: No pox, our way is a little more honourable.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: I have had excellent company of you to day Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: I know thou hast goodness enough to pardon it; but if my design succeeds, you shall have cause to thank me; I will watch this Fellow, as Bacon did his Brazen Head; and (if I do not marry him to thee) I'le be bound never to Cheat the Son of a Citizen again.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Flatter not your self, 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Ne're doubt him, you know not his Art; but whilest he watches him, I'le wait on you to my Lodging; whither he shall bring Timothy as soon as he wakes.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Come on, your servant Mr. Rant.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Your servant sweet Mrs. Ioyce. Mr. Timothy wake a little.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I'le not wake for my Lord Mayor, the Aldermen, and all the Common Council, de' see?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Here waiter, help to carry him into the next Room.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But it is really, as Bellamour tells me, that you would procure the money for another?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Upon my word Sir, the young Gentleman will give you a meeting to morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Tis somewhat better, but why did you keep such scurvy Prodigal company?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I did it only to draw him in, and get money of him.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: That's very well. Now Son I have something else to say to you; the Lady which I intend for your Mother-in-Law, will be here instantly; and I charge you betray not the least dislike of any thing in your Countenance, but use her with all the respect imaginable.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I can't promise you to be glad of the coming of a Mother-in-Law; but I am sure I will not mislike her you have Chosen.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Nor you Daughter

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: I have never given you occasion to suspect so ill a thing of mee.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! what Instrument of the Devil has he made use of, to seduce Isabella hither?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Leave me now, and send in all my servants. [Ex. Theodore and Theodora.] [Enter Oldwoman, Roger, Iames, Will.] Here, where are you all, mind all your Charges. Oldwoman first, to you it belongs to make every thing clean; but do you here, do not Rub my Moveables too hard, to wear them out; if you do, I shall stop your Wages.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Hey, what's to do now?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You Roger take all the Bottles and Glasses, and rince them; and take Charge of 'em, if there be one lost or broke, I'le bate it out of your Wages, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: That I am sure of.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p:
Then do you William fill the drink; but, never but when they are dry, and let 'em call sor't twice, or thrice, pretend to be a little thick of Hearing; here are a company of Roguish Lackey's about the Town, that are always offering
the Glass, and provoking people to drink, and kill themselves, I will have no such Rogues about me.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: I warrant you Sir, I'le look to the Drink.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Then look you have your best Cloathe's on when the people come.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: I have my best, and all I have on, but they are so horribly greasie before, that they are fit for nothing but to give to a Soapboyler, or Kitchin-stuff-woman.

sp.speaker: William.
sp.p: And mine are so full of holes behind, as if I had a Volley of Musket-Bullets in my Posteriors.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You foolish Knaves, cannot you Sirrah take your Hat, and hold it before you to hide the Grease? And do you Sirrah turn your Face always to the people, to hide those holes behind; and when you are sent for any thing, go backward, thus you Rascal. Now to you Iames.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Would you speak to me as your Cook, or Coachman? for you know I serve in both Offices.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: As my Cook.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Good Sir hold a little.

div.stage: [He puts off his Coach-mans Cloak, and appears like a Cook.]

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What a Devil is this Ceremony for? you Rascal.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Good Sir have a little patience: Now speak, I am ready.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh Bellamour come and assist me; Iames, I am to give a Supper to night.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: The most miraculous thing I ever heard of!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Can you make us good Cheer?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Yes, if you will let me have a great deal of money.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Money! you Rascal you, have ye nothing to say but money; nothing in your mouth but money, money, money?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I never heard so impertinent an answer, every fool can do that; but you must make a good entertainment with a little money.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Good Mr. Steward, I would you would teach me that secret.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Peace Sirrah, and tell me what we must have.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: There's your Fac-totum, let him till you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Answer me, or I'le break your head.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Hold Sir, I will, how many will there be?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Ten in all, but provide enough but for eight.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Why you must have, first, two great Soupes made of Veal, Ducks, Chickens, Coxcombs, Sweet-Breads, Mushromes, Palates, Forced-meat, Artichoak-bottoms.—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Sdeath you Rogue, you would Feast all the Town.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Then Fricasees, Ragousts, a huge Dish (with all sorts of Fowles) as Duck, Teal—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue you Rogue, you would undoe me.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Then Plover, Dotril—

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hold you Rogue.

div.stage: [He stops Iame's mouth with his hand.]

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Snipes, Ruffs, Woodcocks.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hold you Dog, he puts me into a cold sweat.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Partridges, Gnats, Godwits.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Will the Rogue never have done?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Pheasants, Heath-Pouts, Black-Cocks, Quails, Rails, Larks, &c.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What do you intend to cramm all the Town? my Master does not invite people, to Murder 'em with eating.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: But he would not starve 'em sure.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: People should eat to live, not live to eat; as the Proverb says.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: O dear Bellamour, let me Embrace thee for that word, he was a great man that said that; I will have that Sentence Engraven in Great Letters over my Hall Chimney.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ne're trouble him Sir, I'le take care of the Supper.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Pray do Sir, with a little money, we shall see what 'twill be.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: But now for my Coach.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Hold good Sir, good Sir hold a little: Now Sir, what were you saying of your Coach?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Let it be clean'd, and the Horses Harnessed.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p:
Horses Sir, why they are in that poor Condition,
that a man must stretch devillishly to call 'em Horses; they are but the Shadows or Ghosts of Horses.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Can they be sick and do nothing?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Yes Sir, you make 'em keep such severe Lents, they eat no more than Chamelions; I look every day when they should depart this life: For my part, it grieves my heart, for I have a tender love and respect for my Horses; and indeed a man should not be so hard hearted, or unnatural, not to pitty his Neighbour in distress.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The Journey will not be far.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: I have not the Courage to put 'em in; how can they draw the Coach, that cannot draw their Legs after them.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, I'le engage one to drive 'em.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: I had rather they should die under any bodies hands than mine; but you have a mighty necessary man here to your Superintendent.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Peace you unmannerly Rascal.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'le about these things instantly.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Do good Bellamour.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Sir, I cannot endure these Flatterers, and Pickthanks, I speak my mind plainly; and it made me mad to hear him say things to your Face, of you, that none of all mankind besides will say.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why, what does the world say of me?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Pardon me Sir, you'l be angry if I tell you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: On the contrary, it will please me infinitely to see that plain dealing in you, let the world say what they will.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Truly I must deal plainly with one I love, and (next to my Horses) you are the person in the world, that I have the greatest respect for.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come speak.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p:
Why Sir, in plain honest sincerity of heart, I tell you in short, no man gives one good word of you; one says you never fail to pick Quarrels with your Servants at Quarter day, that you may turn 'em away without their Wages, that you have been taken Robbing of your own Horses of their Provender: That (when you go by water to your house at Putney) you take a Sculler, and make him bate half his Fair,
for your helping him to Row; in short, you would Rob, Pick, Pockets, Murder, betray your Countrey, and do any Villany in the world for money; your Name is never used without Cursing, and calling you Villain, Wretch, Knave, common Barreter, Oppressor, Horse-Leech.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You are a Rogue, a Son of a Whore, a Dog, a Rascal.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: I was affraid this would be the end on't, a pox on plain dealing for me; did you not command me to tell you?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I'le teach you how to speak Rogue another time.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Well, I see it is not safe for any man to be honest in this Age.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How now Mr. Iames, your plain dealing is rewarded very ill.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: 'Sdeath do you make sport at my beating? Laugh at your own, when you have one.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay prethee be not passionate.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: He intreats me, I'le huff a little and try [Aside.] if he fears me: Do you know Sir that I cannot endure to be laught at? and that I will make you laugh in another fashion.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay softly Iames, if you please.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: No Sir, it does not please me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nay good Iames.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: You are a very impertinent Fellow.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Have patience a little.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: I will have none; if I take a Cudgel, I will so Chastise you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How Rascal a Cudgel, did you say a Cudgel?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: No no no Sir, alas I have no occasion for one, not I.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do you think I am to be beaten Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Alas Sir not I, I have better thoughts of you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Are you not a Son of a Whore?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Yes Sir, any thing in the world, what you please, I am a Son of a Whore Sir, a Son of a damn'd Whore.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do you know me Rascal?

div.stage: [Bellamour pursues Iames, who retires round about the Stage.]

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: O Lord Sir, I honour you abundantly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Did you say you would Cudgel me?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: I was in jesting, I did but Droll upon my honour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And I shall beat you in jesting.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Hold, hold, for heaven's sake.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Remember Sirrah, against another time, you are a very scurvy Railleur.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: A pox on all sincerity, and plain dealing for me, I have had a couple of good substantial beatings; but if I be not reveng'd on this domineering Fellow, I will give Dogs leave to piss upon me.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Do you know whether your Master be within?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: A pox on't, I know but too well.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Pray tell him, we are here.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: But (that I am bound to obey my Mother) you should never have made me run my selfe into the danger of seeing this old man, for (though his Daughter, whom I come to wait on, I hear is an excellent person, yet) I strangely apprehend the trouble of seeing him.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Consult your Interest Madam, he's very rich, and very old, and will leave you a great deal of money, that may qualifie you to marry any young Gentleman you please, hereafter.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: But I have a natural antipathy to old men, as some have to Cats.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: This old man will not have the Impudence to trouble your Ladyship above a year, after you are Married to him.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: I shall never wait for that time, to make my self happy; one year of such punishment would out-weigh all the pleasure, I could have all my life after.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: I find the young Brisk Gentlemen you spoke of yesterday is still in your head.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: He is I confess, and in my heart too, and I think nothing will e're get him out; he keep's such a stir there, he will never let me rest a minute.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Do you know who 'tis Madam?

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: No, but I have often seen him walking by my Lodging, and perpetually looking up at the Balcony, either upon me when I was there, or watching for my coming thither; and by his look, and air, I guess all is not well with him neither; I hope he's in the same condition with my selfe.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Here comes the old Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: What Spectacle's that?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: God save you Lady, I am obliged to you for the honour you do my poor house, which (if you can love an old man,) know Lady I am above six and fifty, and it shall be yours: What a devil Mrs. Cheatly! she answers nothing, nor shews any kind of pleasure at the sight of me.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: O Sir! she's surprised extreamly; besides, Maids endeavour what they can to hide their affections; she is so full of joy, she cannot speak to you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: That's something indeed.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: What a prodigious, ridiculous old Fellow is this?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What says my fair one?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: That you are a most admirable person.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Fair Lady, you do me too much honour.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: What an abominable, odious old Fellow's this!

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I am infinitely obliged Madam, for your good opinion of me: Here's my Daughter Madam.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: Madam, I have too long delay'd waiting on you, but I hope you will pardon it.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Madam, you do what I ought to have done; 'Twas on my part, to have prevented you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Here's my Son comes to kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: Oh Mrs. Cheatly! what accident's this? This is the young Gentleman I spoke of.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: This is wonderful.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I see you are a little amazed to see me have such lusty Children, but I will soon be rid of them both.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p:
Madam, this is an adventure which I did not
expect; nor was I ever in my life so surprised, as when my Father told me his design.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: Sir, I am not less surprised then you, I assure you, I was not at all prepar'd for what I see now.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Madam, my Father cannot in the world make so fair a Choice, and I am infinitely happy to see you here; but you are the person in the world, I would not have my Mother-in-Law; that would break my heart: Madam, I know you have apprehension enough to take what I say in the right sence, and not be offended at it.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You coxcomb, what an impertinent, silly complement is this! you must be making confessions, must you?

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: Sir, we are so much upon even terms, that you are the man in the world, whom I would not have my Son-in-Law; and (if I were not brought here by an absolute power,) I should have given you no shadow of suspition.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: She is in the right, your complement deserves no better return; I know you would anger her: I beg you Madam to forgive my Son's impertinence, he's a young Sot, that does not understand himself.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: What he said, was so far from offending me, that it pleased me extreamly to hear him so frankly declare his opinion, and (if he had spoke in any other manner) I should have esteemed him less.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You have a great deal of goodness to forgive his faults; in time hee'l be wiser, and change his opinion.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Sir, I can never be capable of changing, and Madam, I beg of you to believe me.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Sdeath what extravagance is this?

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Brother, you will provoke him too much.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: 'Sdeath Sir, would you have me lye?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Again, I say change the discourse, you Sot.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p:
Well Sir, since you command me to speak in another fashion, give me leave Madam to put my self in my Fathers place; and now Madam, I protest to you I never yet saw so charming a creature: This is the happiest minute of my life, indeed my life began but from the time I saw you; the Name of your husband, is an honour, which I would prefer
to the Titles of all the Princes upon Earth; and there is nothing which I would not dare to do, for so glorious a conquest.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Softly, hold a little.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: 'Tis a complement I make for you to this Lady.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I have a Tongue to express my selfe, I need no advocate.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: I am not so dull of apprehension not to know for whom that complement was intended, and am glad to find it.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Sir, if you please let us take the air, I hear your Coach at the door.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh is it? but I am sorry you will make such hast, I have not time to prepare you a Collation before you go.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Sir, I foresaw that, and provided beforehand upon your account, a great Dish of China Oranges, Cittrons, all sorts of Sweet-meats, Limonades, Sherbets, and all sorts of Wines.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: Softly, but in anger. Villain, who gave you commission to do this.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Pardon me Sir, if there be not enough, I know this Lady has goodness enough to excuse it; besides I can soon have more.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Is the Sot mad?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Madam did you ever see a finer Stone, than that Diamond upon my Father's finger?

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: It sparkles delicately.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.l: With your leave Sir.
sp.stage: [He takes it off his Fathers finger, and gives it Isabella.]
sp.l: Madam be pleased to look on't nearer.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What means the Rascal.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: It is a delicate clear Stone indeed.

div.stage: [She is going to give it Goldingham, Theodore puts himself between her and his Father.]

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: No Madam, no returning of it, it is in too fair hands already, it is a Present, my Father makes to you Madam.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Who I?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Is it not true, that you would have this Lady keep the Ring?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What do you mean you Villain, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Madam, he desires you, by me, that you would please to accept of it.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The fear, she will take it, distracts me.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: Pardon me Sir, I use not to receive Presents.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Madam, I am sure my Father will never receive it.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh this lying Rascal! you are mistaken.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Look you Madam, your Refusal has made him stark distracted.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: O this damn'd Villain!

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Do you not see how he frets, and fumes? for heaven's sake Madam receive it.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: Well Sir, (rather than offend you Father,) I will keep it.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Sdeath I am undone, but there is no remedy. Madam, I thank you for the favour you do me. But would they were all hang'd, and I had my Ring again.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Sir, there's one to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I am engag'd, I cannot come.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: He has brought you money.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh has he, I ask your Pardon Madam: Remember to go backward Will.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: You have infinitely provoked my Father, and yet I could not but be pleased with it.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I had a violent temptation upon me, that I could not resist Madan; will you do us the honour to take part of this Collation.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: Your humble servant Sir.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Come Madam.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: I attend your Ladyship.

div.head: ACT. IV.
SCE. IV.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: MAdam, you are one of the most hard hearted Ladies that ever triumphed over man.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: And you the most violent Lover, that ever attaqued a woman; but this storme of love, is too great to last.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Never blame this violence, 'tis the best quality a Lover can have, to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Madam, my Brother has made me his confident in this affair, and I can answer for his truth; do not think me partial, for I assure you, I will value your interest equal with his, or with my own.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: You extreamly oblige me with your kindness; and your friendship will be able to sweeten all misfortunes that can happen to me.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: You Lovers had need have something to sweeten, for ye are an unlucky fort of people.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Love, when inclinations meet, is the only condition to be enjoy'd. Love! there is no life without it; we do but sleep, and dream we live, when we are not in love; and pray Madam will you be pleased to wake out of this dream, and think a little of one that loves you so, that his life or death depends upon your breath.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: You let me take no breath Sir.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: A good Souldier, when he has made a breach, assaults it presently; and never gives time to repair, and fortifie.

sp.speaker: Isa • ella.
sp.p: But extemporary love, is most commonly as Hypocritical, as extemporary prayer: But if not dissembl'd, 'tis seldom constant.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Let me beg to know your resolutions, must I live or die?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Come Madam, be merciful, and reprieve the Gentleman, that may be otherwise so far given over as to hang himself for your Ladyships love.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Let me beg you will please to encourage my Brothers affection, which I am sure is true, and honourable.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: Madam, think your self in my place, and imagine whether I have not given too much incouragement for the first time; and whether it becomes my honour to give more.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Pox o' this canting word Honour, it never did good yet, it is often the occasion of Killing men, and prevents the getting of 'em. [Aside.] [To Isabella] Madam, there is no honour but in love, the rest is but a shadow of honour; which the Authors of Romances have perplext with intricacies, more than the Schoolmen have Divinity.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: You give me no time to think of love.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I that have so little time, ought to make what use I can of this; if my Father perceives this, he will with all the malice that can be, seek to prevent me.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: But Sir, I have a Mother (whom yet I never disobey'd,) that hath engag'd her self to your Father; and though I confess, I can never think of marrying him, yet I must think of no other, without her consent.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: This is you that made that engagement, I thank you, a Plague of all Matchmakers; but I must make [Aside.] use of her yet, & not undeceive Isabella in the Character of her.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Sir, I did not know you had a passion here, but I will make you amends: if I can marry her to Theodore [Aside] he's liberal, and will reward me well; but his Father is the most hidebound Fellow—he has the Villany of fifty Iews, and, which is more, of ten London Brokers in him.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Madam, let me have but some assurance, not to to have your unkindness, and all other oppositions in the world are trifles.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p:
Come Mrs. Isabella, hold off no longer; in short, you told me you loved this Gentleman violently, and wish't he were captivated with you; you did not wish it, that you might use him ill; therefore, since 'tis your inclination, dissemble
no longer: Here's the Gentleman, take him by the hand, he is your own ipso facto, he's a proper Gentleman, make much of him; here he is for you, and there's the short and the long on't. Now Mr. Theodore I think I have made you amends.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Can I believe so great a happiness, I am so transported Madam, you must expect no sense from me.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: Sir, since she has betray'd my weakness, which she for her Sex sake ought to have concealed, and I ought in modesty not to have told you, pardon my easiness, and think me not guilty of levity, if you do, you will be very unjust to censure one that esteemes you so well.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I should as soon censure heaven for granting my prayers; I have not words enough to tell you how welcome this minute is to me.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Now I hope you will do me the honour to let me call you Sister.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: I shall be proud to be call'd so by you, but I cannot be so till my Mother consents.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Shall I have your leave Madam, to use all the means I can to procure her consent?

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: I freely give you leave to do and say what ever you can to obtain it; but I believe you will find it hard to break off her engagement with your Father.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Now comes my part, to set my braines on work, I'le shew you the mastery of my Art, and make your Father break off first.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: It is impossible he should be such a wretch as as willingly to quit so great a Prize.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: I warrant you, trust me, there is one of my acquaintance who I will perswade him is worth 500. l. more than this Lady; and though Madam he loves you very much, yet he loves a little money much more: This friend of mine is but a Taylors Daughter, but I will make her Act a Countess with some odd Title; and she can behave her selfe as proudly and statelily, as the best of 'em, I will make him believe that she has a very great mind to marry him for his care and thrift, &c. This may make him release my Lady of her engagement.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I think you have reason.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Reason ay, I think so; if I han't, who should have it? alas I have done things that shall be nameless, that no woman of intrigue but my self has been capable of, though I say it; and if I do not bring this about, I will never pretend to an intrigue again.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: You will infinitely oblige me.

sp.speaker: Foot-Boy.
sp.p: Madam, my Lady your Mother desires your company instantly.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: I wait on her. Madam, if possible I will wait on you at Supper.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: I hope your affairs will permit you to do us that honour.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Let me have the honour to wait upon you to your Mother; and be pleas'd to make me so happy as to assist me in perswading her to break off the Engagement with my Father.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: A man of your deserts needs no advocate with me, I am sure. Madam, your humble servant: your servant Mrs. Cheatly.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Now Madam I have something to impart to your Ladyship's privacy.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: To me, what is it?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Your Ladyship is very young, and mighty Pritty, really I have never seen so charming an eye, so delicate an air in any Face, so excellent, such pleasant motion, and so bewitching a way—

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Pray Madam don't raily me at this rate—

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: I protest Madam I speak my opinion. Now Madam there is an acquaintance of mine is extreamly taken with your Ladyship; he is one of the hansomest and most accomplisht Sparkes in Town: He has fifteen hundred Pound a year, and his love is honourable too; now if your Ladyship will be pleased to walk in Grays-Inn walks with me, I will design it so that you shall see him, and he shall never know on't.

sp.speaker: Theodora,
sp.p: I ask your pardon, I have no thoughts of putting my self off to Sale; but when I have, that Mart is too scandalous.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: In the Mulbery-Garden, then Madam, he shall never know of it; I vow the poor Gentleman is ready to die for your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: You must excuse me.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: In Covengarden Church, will you see him? I'le order it so with him that keeps the Gallery, that you shall both set together there.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: I assure you, I carry no such thoughts about me to Church.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Mrs. Cheatly, your Daughter ha's urgent business with you, and desires you to come home immediately; I find Mr. Squeeze is there privately.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: I thank you dear Robin. Madam, I hope to convince you next time I see you; in the interim I kiss your Ladyships hand.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Your servant. [Ex. Cheatly and Robin.] [To her self.] This woman I fear is a little scandalously given, I will not trust her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh Madam I have been seeking you at the Park, and the Mulbery-Garden; and thought it an Age till I saw you.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: What's the matter? you look as if you had some ill news for me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am sorry I must tell you, that which we must speedily provide against. Your Father has prepared an entertainment, and will have a Hackney Parson ready, that will venture all his Perferment, and go against the Canonical Hour, to marry you this night to that Rascal Timothy: and in spight of all my perswasion, your Father is resolv'd on't.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: How sudden are these resolutions? I shall not need to counterfeit sickness, I shall have enough when I see him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Be pleased suddenly to make use of that Artifice; and if that prevent not, I hope you will give me leave to own my person, and my love.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: What disease must I make choice of now?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Here's one comes to help you to one.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: sings. Diseases and troubles are ne're to be found,
But in the damn'd place where the Glass goes not round.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is lucky, above my wishes; he is very drunk, and that will certainly defeat your Fathers intention; this night, if you dare trust your self with him, I'le bring your Father to see him in this condition.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Pray do, it will do very well.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Oh dear Mistriss, have I found you! let me Salute you, de' see?

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Hold Sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nay prethee Mrs. Thea don't be so coy, look what I have brought you here; here's a Bottle of Campaigne, I think they call it, and almost a whole Neats-Tongue, and a power of Sweet-Meats, for you dear Mrs. Thea, there they are.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: This Fellow has that advantage by nature, that not drunkenness, nor any condition can make him worse.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Well Mrs. Thea, I have been with the finest Ladies, and the merriest Gentlemen; we did rant, and roar, and sing, and tear, Hey, Diseases and Troubles are, &c. Faith I am as drunk as a Drum, or as the driven Snow, or as Davids Sow, as the saying is, de' see? Hey, fa la la la, prethee dear Mrs. Thea let me kiss thee now, nay prethee do, nay shaw poise on't.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Be not so passionate good Sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nay peuh, I can't abide this, you might have given one a fall now, would I might ne're stir; but 'tis no matter for that, I'le drink six go-downs upon reputation in Campaigne to your health, de' see? I can be merry when I set on't: i' faith here's your health upon my knees, de' understand me? Oh if I had but Fiddles to play a health now!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Do you see Sir how abominably drunk he is?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: He is a little in Beer, he is; he is disguis'd, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
There Mrs. Thea I have done it, faith you shall pledge
me by word of mouth; de' see, nay fack I am sound, you may drink after me, de' conceive me?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You see Sir he is too drunk to be married to night.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come come, he's the fitter for't, for being drunk, if he be sober, he may repent him, and ask a Portion: stay here, I will fetch a Parson immediately.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is worse and worse, Madam did you hear him?

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Yes to my grief, I must into my Chamber, and be very sick.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Nay, if you stir I am a Rogue, a very Rogue, de' see? wee'l be very merry, Diseases and Troubles, &c.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Who taught you this insolence? unhand her.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Why you saucy Fellow you, what's to do with you? Ha, you are so purdy.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Where's Mr. Timothy Squeeze?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: 'Slife, what makes this Rascal here? if I do not carry him off, I lose the hopefullest Bubble in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Where's Mrs. Thea, Mrs. Thea?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Mr. Timothy come along with me, Mrs. Ioyce is impatient till she see's you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I'le not stir till I see Mrs. Thea, where's Mrs. Thea? Hey, Hey.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She says you are a drunken Rascal, and she will have you kick'd out.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Does she so? would I might ne're stir if I do not do her errand to her Father.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Come away and leave her: Mrs. Ioyce is a person of Quality, and Fortune, and will use you with more civility.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I know she's a fine person, and I'le wait on her, but I am resolved to stay till Mr. Goldingham comes, that I may tell him of this Gilflirt his Daughter.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Nay then, I must to my last shift; Bayliffs come in.

sp.speaker: Bayliff.
sp.p: I Arrest you, at the Suit of Humphrey Nit a Barber.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sirrah, you lie like a Rogue, I owe him not a farthing.

sp.speaker: Bayliff.
sp.p: No Sir, but you did vi et armis break, or cause to be broken a very large Window, where he us'd to expose his Flaxen Periwigs.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Is that all? I'le Bail him for that—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Will you? nay then I'le break 'em again, I'le break Windows with e're a Gentleman that wears a head.

sp.speaker: Bayliff.
sp.p: Come come and talk of these things in another place.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay with all my heart, Diseases and Troubles, &c. What a pox care I, come.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is a lucky Fellow that came in to our rescue.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Dear brother, I am glad I have found you, I have a design, and upon my Father too, in which I am confident you will joyn.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: —You may be sure to command me in any thing.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I know some may blame me, but love excuses all.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Love, like the Crown, takes away all Attainders.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: My design is to work so upon my Fathers covetousness, as to draw him into a Plot against the Government; and he is you know, a mighty well wisher to the damn'd good old Cause, yet.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This will be dangerous tampering with; how can you draw him into one, without being guilty your self?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: It shall be but a seeming Plot, you may be sure; I would not engage my self in a real one; 'tis only a design to invert the order of nature for a while, and keep my Father in awe.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How can you contrive it?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I have several great Chests almost full of Lumber, but cover'd on the top with a great many fine Arms, here he comes, I have not time to tell you the rest; but pray second me, in what I shall say to him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I'le not examine your design, but serve you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Have you the confidence to appear before me, after your giving my Ring away, and sending for those mountains of Sweet-Meats, and that Ocean of Wine and Limonades?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I humbly beg your pardon; but I thought I had done well, since you commanded me to shew all the respect imaginable to my intended Mother-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Respect with a pox, de' call it?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I beseech you be not angry, I'le get your Ring again for you, and put you in a way to get forty Guinnes this night, but I must be very private in it.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: How! can you do that? then I will forgive all your extravagance; but how is it? speak, you may trust Bellamour.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Sir, there is one that was my Shcool-fellow, that I am very well acquainted with, that is called a Phanatick according to the flesh, he (after he had made me take an Oath of Secrecy, told me of a design his Brethren had, who (out of pure Zeal against Surplice and Common Prayer Book) were resolved upon an insurrection, and to sieze in one night upon Whitehal, and the Exchequer.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What say you?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: They have accordingly provided Arms and Ammunition, which they dispose of in packs of goods; to their secret friends, and well wishers, for which they reward them liberally.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What can this come to?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: He remembring that (when we were Boys together) I had shewn him a secret Vault in the Garden, that is known but to few, propounded to me the concealing six Chests of Armour there, and promised forty Guinnes, and an Oath of Secrecy; this Sir you may chuse, whether you will accept of or no, but I thought I was obliged in duty to tell you, knowing you take all occasions whatsoever for the getting of money.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I got a good part of my Estate by Rebellion (as many other Estates were raised) but I would be loath to lose it by Rebellion again.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: There is no danger, we will all take Oaths of Secrecy.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Ready money Sir is not to be despised, 'tis a precious thing.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: There spoke an Angel.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Besides Sir, if the Chest should be discover'd, (which will be almost impossible) some of your Swcarers in Ordinary shall testifie you took 'em in Pawn.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The money is sweet, but the attempt is [Aside.] dangerous; hold to Theodore. Now Sir, I am glad you have put me in a way to be revenged of you for all your Villanies; I will immediately acquaint the King with your Treason, and you shall be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: For heaven's sake, betray not your own Son.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: My Loyalty is dearer to me than Son and Daughter, and all the Relations in the world; I will hang him, I'le to the King immediately.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I am at your disposal Sir, but be pleased to remember I did this for your advantage, and out of love and duty to you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No Sir, I will hang you, never speak on't; farewel, shall I betray my Countrey?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Hold Sir, for Heaven's sake conceal it, I will return the twenty Guinnes he gave in earnest; here they are, I will go and give 'em him immediatly.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Did he give you twenty Guinnes, hum?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and promised twenty more at the delivery of the Chests.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Fourty Guinnes is a most delicious Sum, where are they? let me see them.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Here they are Sir, but I beseech you be not angry; I will carry them immediately.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hold, it may be there's no necessity of that— I would hang this Rogue; but fourty Guinnes, dear fourty Guinnes.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He comes on a pace.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Sir, I will by no means offend you with the sight of 'em, I am gone.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Stay I say, and let me see them.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I am afraid it will provoke you to talk any more of this business▪ do not be offended, I will return them instantly.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Sdeath Sir, I will see them.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: There they are Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Oh Sir, how I could hug that Gold.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Ay Bellamour, does it not look beautifully? they talk of the beauty of women; but give me the beauty of Gold, Oh dear, dear, sweet Gold.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Shall I return 'em Sir?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No Sir, you shall not: Oh dear, dear Guinnes, are we all secret?

sp.speaker: Bellamour. Theodore.
sp.p: We are.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Swear never to reveal this.

sp.speaker: Bellamour. Theodore.
sp.p: We do Swear.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Well Son, your importunity at last has overcome me, when shall these Arms be delivered?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: This night at ten a Clock.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Do you Bellamonr see it done, and take his Oath of Secrecy. But I had forgot, where is Mr. Timothy? the Parson is ready in the Parlour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He was Arrested here by Bayliffs, for breaking Windows when he was drunk, who have hurried him I know not whither.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Sdeath how unlucky is this! send immediately to all the Bayliffs hereabouts, to find him out; go Bellamour.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Pox on't, I might have saved money, he would have consented to have betray'd his Countrey for half the Sum; and so will any covetous man, that can do it safely.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Sir, I am very glad I have taken you alone; I have a secret to impart to you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Sdeath she's come to borrow money of me.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p:
Though it may be to no purpose, I think it my duty to acquaint you, that I have since I parted with you discovered a Countess that is not above thirty, that is extreamly in love with you for your person, besides your care and
thrift, which she says to me, would be very useful to her in the mannagement and improving of her Fortune, she has five hundred Pounds more than Isabella.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What you are merry, Mrs. Cheatly?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Nay Sir, if you distrust me, there's no hurt done; I did not think you would embrace the offer; but I thought my self bound to discharge my trust, for the truth is, she engaged me (though something unwilling) to use my care in this business.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Why, sure thou art not in earnest?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: If ever you were (when you said your prayers) I am.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: There must be something in this, [To himself.] this is strange Mrs Cheatly.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: You may chuse whether you will believe me or no, for my part I don't desire you should change; for I think if there be any difference, Mrs. Isabella is something more desirable.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Good faith, but if this be true, she is not more desirable, fifty Pounds is a noble Sum, and more than any womans person is worth: for my part fifty Pounds with me would turne the ballance, were there ne're so much difference in their persons. But who is this?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: You must not know, till you see her.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Can all this be true thou tell'st me?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: If I make it not good, I'le forfeit my life; but I'le take my leave now, I have done my errand; but truly Sir, I think you ought not in honour to quit Isabella.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: In good faith but I ought, I take it; Honour! quoth she; lose five hundred Pounds in honour! what a pox care I for their persons in comparison with money?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: I am a little in hast, but I beseech you let not Mrs. Isabella know of this, she will be distracted.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Hold a little, it was unlucky we did not know of this before you brought Isabella acquainted with my Daughter, I shall be troubled with her: but canst thou oblige me to contrive an interview between the Countess and me?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Ay and a Marriage too, if I would; but really I think you are too far engaged to Isabella.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Engag'd, I am not engag'd, I will have nothing to do with her; I will forbid her my house.

sp.speaker: Foot-Boy.
sp.p: Is Mrs. Theodora here?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What would you have with her?

sp.speaker: Foot-Boy.
sp.p: Mrs. Isabella presents her service to her, and says she cannot possibly wait on her at Supper.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, 'tis no matter whether she does or no, go get thee about thy business Lad; go go. This is very lucky: Mrs. Cheatly you'l Sup here.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Sir, I must go home first. Your Servant. This will be joyful news for the two Lovers.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Sir here's a Porter come from Mr. Squeeze, who says he is engaged upon extraordinary business, and cannot Sup here to night.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The Devil take thee for thy news.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Mr. Timothy was at the Rose Sir, under an Arrest, but was Bail'd by Mr. Rant and Mr. Hazard; and is gone along with them we know not whither.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: All my designs are crossed this night, here's my Supper lost, and I have not given one this dozen years before, but I'le make these Rogues fast this month for't; begon Rogues, and call my Son: Oh here he is. [Ex. William and Roger.] [Enter Theodore.] Son I have something to say to you of concernment, pray (now we are alone) speak freely, how do you like this Isabella? (setting aside the name of a Mother-in-Law.)

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I like her, what does he mean?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes, her Air! her Shape! her Beauty! her Wit.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Faith Sir (to speak the truth) she is not what she appear'd to me, she has no Air or Spirit in her Face, her Shape's very indifferent, her Motion awkward, and her Wit little or none, but I like her well enough for a Mother-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: You talked at another rate to her to day.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I only made some few complements to her in your name, I meant not one of 'em▪ I assure you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Do you think you could have no kind of inclination for such a kind of woman?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: No not I Sir, if there were none but such women, I should be out of danger of Gun Shot.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I am sorry to find this, because it breaks a resolution I had made: I had reflected with my self upon Isabella's youth and my age; which are so disproportionable, that I have made choice of another, a Countess too of about thirty years old, that's worth five hundred Pounds more than she.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: How has Cheatly wheadled him already! I'le try him further: Sure Sir you cannot be in earnest.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: By Heaven I am, and (but for this aversion I find in you) I would have Married Isabella to you.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: To me Sir?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes, to you.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: 'Tis a thing I must confe • s I have no inclination in the world to; but I will obey your commands in any thing.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No no, mistake me not, I'le not force your inclination.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Sir, I am easily inclined to any thing you please to impose upon me.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No Sir, I will impose nothing; those Marriages can never be happy where affections do not meet.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I'le sacrifice my affection to interest, and your commands.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No no, if you had loved her, you should have Married her in my stead; but (since you have such an aversion,) I'le follow my first design, and marry her my self.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Then Sir I must speak freely to you, I love her infinitely, and designed to ask your consent at the same time you declared your intention to marry her your self, and you might easily have perceived how that declaration surprised me.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, & did you ever reveal your love to her?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I have Sir, and she received it very kindly; and her Mother too, if you will quit her of her engagement, will freely dispose of her to me.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: And has the Daughter consented to this, say you?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: She has Sir, and I am extreamly happy that you are pleased to give your consent; nothing else could be wanting to compleat my happiness.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I will give you my consent to hang your self, but not to marry her, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Slife I had been finely serv'd, to have been bob'd of my Mistriss, for a story of a Countess of I know not what, this was a fine conspiracy.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: Sir, You are very mysticall, pray let me understand you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I speak plainly: Do not dare once to think of loving this Lady: Have you the impudence to pretend to one whom I reserve for my selfe?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: This makes me mad. Sir, Since you provoke me thus, I doe pretend to her, and will never quit those pretensions but with my life.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Impudent villaine! to speak thus to your Father.

sp.speaker: Theodor.
sp.p: In other things I respect you as my Father, but love knowes no body.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: I will make you know me, or I'le cut your throat.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: A lover, and affraid of threats?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: And shall I that am a love endure this insolence?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: I will not make use of my plot yet, things are not ripe.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Out of my doores you Rascall.

sp.speaker: Theodor.
sp.p: Fare you well Sir,

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: This designe was well scaped; but'le watch your waters I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: My dear, I doubt not thy constancy, so pretty a creature cannot be false to one that loves her as I do.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Indeed I can think of no body but you; the thoughts of you are the last that leave me at night, and the first that salute me in the morning.

sp.speaker: Cheat:
sp.p:
I am sure I am sufficiently troubled with her, she talkes and thinks of nothing but you; if I aske her a question about business, she answers me something about you, and is so out of
humour when you are absent.
sp.l: I hear some body knock.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Alas poor thing! my deare pretty Lettice!

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: My dear Mr. Squeeze, I can find no satisfaction but in thy conversation, 'tis so charming and pleasant.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Thou art the rarest woman upon earth. Let me kiss thy hand upon my knees; [He kneels.] I know thou lovest me, and art true to me, for which I'le reward thee to the full: There's ne're a one of 'em all shall keep his Mistress better than I do; go to the Goldsmiths, and chuse a hundred pounds worth of Plate, I'le send mony for't by an unknown hand.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Alas how can I deserve it? I can returne nothing but my thanks, nor can I desire any thing from you but your constancy. [Aside] upon these termes.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: I will be as constant to thee, as the Sun and Moon are to their courses.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: But I shall have you get a young Wife, and forget mee.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: If I should marry, my Dear, it should be for money, that I might spare the more for thee: besides what married man Loves not his Mistress better than if he were single? a Wife is but a foyle to a Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: 'Tis true, this is the fashionable opinion, but you would be of another mind I feare.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Prethee believe me if I had a Wife, thou should'st have power to turne her out of dores at thy pleasure, thou shouldst ride in myglass Coach when she took a hackney; thou shouldst have my purse, my heart, and every thing: are Wives to be compar'd to Mistresses, that would be a fine age i' faith.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: This is extreame kind, you are a good Man: I could never endure that a Wife should share affection with me, especially from thee my Deare.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Nay, prethee my dear, do not stroke my head, 'tis bald, but 'tis not with age, for I am not above eight and thirty, but the hair came off with a sicknesse.

sp.speaker: Lettice:
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, I like it, I hate them that weare much haire upon their heads, 'tis greazy, and smells ill; but this is so sweet, and clean, and pretty, I could kiss it now.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Oh Daughter, here has been the young Knight you know of; he was so importunate to see you, I thought I should never have got rid of him.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: What's that, pray let me know?

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Nothing Sir,

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Prethee my Dear tell me.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Pray Sir do not aske, it signifies nothing.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: I shall take it unkindly if you do not tell me.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Nay there is nothing I can keep from you: the truth is, my Taylour came to Dun me, but the Rascall shall stay I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: How much is the debt?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Twenty pounds.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: As I am an honest man, but he shall not stay, here's the money, give it him immediately.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir Ieffery Smelsmock is coming up to see Mistriss Lettice; she was denied below, but he would not be answered.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Oh heaven, we are undone, if I stop him not.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: What's the matter, is it another Dun? prethee have comfort I'le send thee 50 l. to morrow morning to discharge all little driblets.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: I could not expect this from you.

sp.speaker: Cheatly
sp.p: to Lettice softly. I have got rid of Sir Ieffery much adoe. Well this Mercer's sawcy fellow, here's a stir for a little money indeed.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Hang him rascal, he shall not have it these six Moneths for his insolence, and I'le have him kickt besides.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: within. Sir, I tell you she is not within.

sp.speaker: Bully.
sp.p: Hold your tongue you insolent rascal! I'le break open [within] the door. Where's Lettice, where is your Ladyship? let me in, or by Heaven I'le break the dore.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: For heavens sake Sir get into the Closset till I get rid of this roaring fellow, I know not who it is.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Ay with all my heart, where is it? I tremble every joint of me.

sp.speaker: Bully.
sp.p: What Madam, your Ladyship Bully bounces and breaks open the Dore, and enters. is grown coy and deny your selfe: What you do this for an old Rascal, they say that keeps you; If I can learn his name, or catch him here once, I'le cut off his eares, and his nose, both his arms, and both his leggs, I will mangle the old dog so.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Oh defend me heaven from this roaring Bully, he puts me in a cold sweat.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Let me beg of you to go into another Room, and I'le satisfie you.

sp.speaker: Bully.
sp.p: Come on, now you are civill.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Would this Bully were hang'd, he'l ruine my daughter. Come Mr. Squeeze, all's clear, come out.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Is he gone, he has put me in a dreadfull fright; this was a Dragon of a Bully▪

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: You see Sir what she suffers for your sake, because she will not yield to the temptations of men.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Ay poor heart, but whither is she gone? Pray heaven she be true to me.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: She must give him faire words till she gets him out, and then she'l wait on you.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Oh me, where is she, she stayes long, pray heaven all be well.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: What is this Girle doing?

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Gad forgive me, will she never come, what is the matter? I am affraid the Bully is not gone.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Why Lettice, will you never come?

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: I hope in Gad she's honest, but I do not like this.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Oh fie upon you, you have been naughtwith this Bully, look how you are Ruffled.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Mum, not a word, I have sent him away much adoe, I'le have him clapt by the heeles if he comes to affront me again like an insolent fellow as he is.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Heaven, what noyse is that there? A noyse without of singing and roaring & Fidlers. there are more roaring Bullies abroad. Let us retire quickly to bed, and bolt the dore upon our selves, my dear Lettice; quickly Mistriss Cheatly barre the dores of the house.

div.stage: Rant, Hazard, Tym: with a sword, two Servants and Fidlers playing, they singing and roaring, Drunk, breaking windowes.

sp.speaker: Tym:
sp.p: Hey let's break windowes in abundance.

sp.speaker: Haz:
sp.p: Ah brave Timothy, thou art as gallant a Bully as a man shall see in a summers day.

sp.speaker: Tym:
sp.p: Here's the Constable, don't you use to beat him alwayes when you see him?

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Yes, and will now.

sp.speaker: Constab:
sp.p: Stand in the Kings name.

sp.speaker: Tym:
sp.p: I can stand in ne're a Kings name in Christendome but we will beat you in the Kings name very exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Constab:
sp.p: Knock ▪em down, fall on Fellowes of the watch.

sp.speaker: Rant:
sp.p: Have at you Rogues that disturbe the Kings Peace, and will not let honest fellowes give serenades, and break windowes in quiet, have at ye.

div.stage: [They fight, the Constable and Watchmen are driven up into a corner.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.p: Hey, have we conquer'd you ye Rogues? lay down your armes.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Lay downe your weapons, or wee'l cut your throats.

sp.speaker: Constab:
sp.p: Well sir, 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Do you mutiny ye Rogues, against Bully Rocks, your Commanders?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Are you offended at the noyse of fiddles? strike up, and sound an alarme in the eares of 'em.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Come Rogues here are just eight They play with their fiddles at their ears. of you; either daunce to these fiddles, or we will slice you into steakes.

sp.speaker: Constab:
sp.p: Ha ha, come fellowes of the watch, wee'l please them for once, they are very merry Gentlemen I fack,

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: 'Tis very well done, there's a crown to drink for you: I, like Iulius Caesar, am generous to foes o're come.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Here's another for you to make ye as drunk as we are.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: And I'le be outdone by no man, there's a broad piece for you, now I have beaten you.

sp.speaker: Rant:
sp.p: Hee's plaguy liberal of our Money. Stay watch and be our guard.

sp.speaker: Constab.
sp.p: We thank ye Gentlemen, and will live and dy with ye.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Strike up here, faith wee'l see Lettice before we have done: Cheatly open the door.

sp.speaker: Cheatly
sp.p: within. We are all abed: what Ruffians are those?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Bounce at the door, break the windowes, hey.

div.stage: Squeeze at a window in, his cap, and undressed.

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: Heart! if I be discovered in this condition I am ruined for ever, my credit in the City will be quite lost: Heaven they have almost broke the door, I must venture to escape at this window. [He leaps down.] Death I have broke my bones; oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: How now, what noyse is that?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Some body leaped out of a window: lets see what old Rogue's this.

sp.speaker: Tim:
sp.p: Ay, what old Rogues this, ha?

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: I was frighten'd out of my Lodging by these Roaring Blades, and I thought to have escaped out of a window.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: Speak to me, I represent the King's person, who are you? what make you here?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Hang him, take him away to the Round house.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: My Son here drunk with Bullies! then all my shame comes together.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: What's here, he has been in bed with a woman, and for hast has mistaken a red silk stocking of hers for his own.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: 'Tis true, away with him an old whoring Rogue.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay away with him, an old Rogue, in bed with a whore! away with him, away with him.

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: We must secure the woman to.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Wee'l secure her, carry him away.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: What a dreadfull mistake was this, I am for ever undone, I am for ever ruined, what shall I do?

div.stage: Ex. Constable and Watch with Squeeze.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: If you will Rant, let's first give Isabella a serenade, and then come hither againe. It will be time too, to bring our buble to Mistress Ioyce againe.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Come along Fiddles, strike up.

sp.speaker: Haz.
sp.p: Rank your selves here, strike up, and put out the lights that we may not be discover'd.

div.stage: [They go off, and come in at another door.]

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Faire Isabella, sweet Isabella! look out and shine upon your servants.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: How now, what Rascals are these: Robin fall on.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Are you so briske?

div.stage: They fight, and Theodore is driven back,

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This must be Theodore and his man that are engaged, I parted from 'em but just now.

div.stage: Enter Bellamour and Ioynes with Theodore, and they beat the other off the Stage.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Fly, shift for your selves, the day is lost.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Who's this that is so kind to draw his sword for us? my dear Brother, is it you? a thousand thanks to you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No words, but lets pursue the Rogues.

div.head: ACT. V.
SCE. I.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: I Wonder who those Fellows were we rancounter'd last night.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Very active nimble youths, they ran like Irish Foot-men.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: If we had catch'd 'em, we would have paid 'em for scouring under that Window: But now I can think of nothing else but love. Revenge has given place to that. Yesternight I got a promise from my Mistress, and am within this hour to meet her, and marry her privately in the City; this day will make me richer than the Indies can.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I congratulate your good Fortune, but cannot envy any man, since I am happy in my Theodora's love.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Here's a Letter Mr. Bellamour came by the Post for you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: For me!

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: What is it that disturbes you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: News that nothing could make tollerable to me, but that it puts me into a condition of serving my Theodora better then I could before.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: My Father has been dead these nine months, and died without a Will; my younger Brother is at present possest of the Estate, and has inhumanly put my Mother and Sister out of the house, who live privately in this Town, somewhere about Covengarden. This account I have received from my man, who is hasting up to Town to me.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
Bell.
sp.p: I have now no time to railly with you, I'le to my dear Theodora, and hope to get her into so good a humour, that we shall not be long after you in Marriage: adieu.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: What ever you are in that, I am sure you are before hand with me in the death of a Father. How now Bullies, are you up so early? sure you have lain rough, or have not slept to night.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: How now Lover that are, and Whore-Master that was, you are full of your bobs.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: What I warrant you, you are got up early to Write a fashionable Sonnet, without sense, upon the Divine Isabella.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: How many Stars, Moons, Suns, Alabasters, Roses, Pearls, and Rubies, have you made use of for similies?

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Come prethee communicate, let's see the labour of thy Muse.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: As I live, drunk still: but Gentlemen I hate the name of a Muse, as I do that of a Baud; were I a Poet I would invoke Creswell or Gifford before any Muse in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Faith thou art in the right, for they tw • can supply our necessities better than all the nine Muses.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: But this is not our business, here is a young Gentleman at the door call'd Mr. Timothy Squeeze, that comes to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Hang him Rascal, keep him to your selves, he's fitter for your purpose; have you fleec'd him soundly?

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Very sufficiently I assure you, but he is come upon a pleasant occasion; he says he has done you, and your Family such an injury.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Pox on him, I will forgive him any but the trouble of his company.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Thou shalt see him, and when he tells thee his condition, thou wilt find we have Reveng'd thee to the full; I'le fetch him in.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: How have you us'd the Rogue? you have won all his money.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: That's not all, but I'le not forstall you, you shall be surprised into your pleasure; he beg'd of us to make him friends with you for fear you should kill him, he fears not your Father.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Are you sure he will do me no hurt?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: I am, speak to him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sir, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Sir, Yours.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I beg your pardon from the bottom of my heart, for an injury I have done you, and your Family.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Pray Sir be not in passion, and I'le tell you, you know Sir I should have have been your Brother-in-Law Sir; and lastnight it seems I was overtaken in Campaigne, and as these Gentlemen tell me (for I vow I remember not a word on't) I married one Mrs. Ioyce, Mr. Hazards Cousin Sir: But your Sister sent me word she would have me kick'd out of the house Sir lastnight, or I should not have done it on my cnoscience Sir; I find I did it in passion really.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Oh brave Bullies, now you have Revenged me sufficiently.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Now Sir, I hope in God you will please to forgive me since I married in drink; and I vow to God Sir, as I am an honest man, I meant no more hurt in't Sir, than I do at this present; for I wak'd this morning Sir, and found my self in Bed with the said Mrs. Ioyce, de' understand me, (and I vow she's a pure Bed-fellow that's the truth on't) but at first I was frighted, and wondr'd what a dickens was the matter, when these Gentlemen came up with a Cawdle to me, and fac'd me down I was married Sir, and at last shew'd me the Ring, the Licence, and the Parsons Certificate Sir.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: No more Sir, I forgive you freely Sir.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Sir I am beholding to you; but if there be an offence you must blame those Gentlemen; for I protest and vow I intended to marry Mrs. Thea, or would I might ne're stir out of
this place alive.
