But I tell you in private, if I had not married the aforesaid Mrs. Ioyce, I believe they would have forc'd me to it: for my part Sir, I don't like 'em; for between you and I, they won above forty Pound on me. But to give the Devil his due, the Gentlewoman is a Pretty Gentlewoman, and they say has a good Portion.

sp.speaker: Theodore
sp.p: To Hazard and Rant. This relation pleases me, but pray take away your Fool, for I have business of great concernment.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: This was all we had to say to you. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Tim come along, dear soul.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay come Cousin [To Theodore.] Sir your Servant to command.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Sir, I have a Present for you, but let us begon Sir, and take it in another place; pray follow me, I am weary with carrying it.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: What means the fellow?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Here is a Chest of money of your Fathers that was hid in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Of my Fathers! how camest thou by it?

sp.speaker: Robin.
Theodore.
sp.p: This is a lucky supply.

div.stage: Enter at another door William, Cheatly, and Bridget, with a Page.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Is Madam Theodora within?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: She is gone out with Mr. Bellamour.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Is not your Master within?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: We expect him every minute Madam.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Now Mrs. Bridget, can you represent a Stately Countess.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Never fear me; Page hold up my Train Sirrah, I can beare my head as high as any Lady in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Remember when any body Salutes you, to turne your Cheek to him, as great Ladies use; that's very convenient too, for concealing a tainted breath.

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: Mine is not so, but I'le not forget it.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: But thou hast so used to offer thy mouth, that thou wilt forget it.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh Sir, your Servant, the Countess of Puddle Dock is come to see Mrs. Theodora.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: [Aside.] Countess of Puddle-Dock! I never heard of that Title, it may be 'tis some Scotch or Irish Title.

sp.speaker: To Bridget.
sp.p: Madam I kiss your Honour's hand: where is my Daughter that she comes not to wait on her Honour.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Not within. This is the Countess I spoke of

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Let me see; if this be a Countess, and has such a Fortune, no more then of Isabella; but I must into the Garden to my dear Gold. Madam I'le wait on your Honour presently.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Is not this an amiable old Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Bridget.
sp.p: As bad as he is, I am not so nice, but I could make shift with him.

sp.speaker: Golding
sp.p: within.] Murder, murder, Oh Theeves, theives.

sp.speaker: Cheat.
sp.p: What's the meaning of this, is the man mad.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: Thieves, thieves, murder, murder, death, devils, damnation, Hell and furies, thieves, thieves, I am undone, undone, they have cut my throat, they have murder'd me, they have stole my money, where is it? what's become on't? where are the Thieves? where have they hid themselves? whither shall I go to find'em? what shall I do? shall I run? shall I stay? are they here? are they there? where are they?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: What is it transports you thus?

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: Oh are you here, give me my money, [He tugs and hales Cheatly.] where's my Gold, confess, or I'le rack you, where is my dear Gold, my poor Gold, give it me, conceale it no longer.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Help, help, will you murder me?

sp.speaker: Bridg.
sp.p: Are you Mad, 'tis Mrs. Cheatly.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: Another, is there more of your number, I will hang ye all, where is my money, Money, Money?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: What's the Matter Sir,

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Come Countess, 'tis time to shift for our selves.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: falls on 'em with his Caine. Oh you thieves, my Gold, my Gold, give me my Gold, I'le hang ye, I'le drown ye, I'le murder ye all; oh my Gold, must I lose thee?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: He raves help to hold him.

div.stage: [He breaks from them, they run away.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: I have lost my money, my life, my blood, my entrals, my heart, my vitalls, I dye, I am dead, I am buried, will no body save my life, and help me to it, oh I am mad, what say you, will you, hum; alas I am mad, there's no body: Oh my money, my soule, Justice, Justice, I will hang all the Towne, if Isabella has a hand in't I will hang her, I will beg the help of Constables, Beadles, Churchwardens, Baylies, Sergeants, Justices, Aldermen, Judge, Gibbet, Gallowes, and Hangmen: I will hang my son and daughter if they be guilty: and if I find not my Money I will hang my self.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: My master Sir is Mad, be pleased to command him in his Majesties name to keep his worships wits.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: Oh neighbour Justice, you are come in season, I am rob'd undone, make me a Mittimus.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: For whom neighbour Goldingham.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: For all Covengarden, I will hang every body, oh my Gold.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: You'l spoyl all, if you be thus outragious, we must examine such things privately, or you will never have notice of your Money.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: Oh my money, I cannot containe my selfe, but if you will assist me, I'le endeavour.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Ha, is my Master Rob'd? now I may be fully revenged of our dominus factotum for my beating, and other things. [To Gold.] I am mistaken, or I can give you some light into this business.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: Speake what can you say, if you do not discover it, I will hang you.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: I do certainly believe that Mr Bellamour has it.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: What he that appear'd so true, and faithfull to me?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: The same Sir, I believe 'tis he that has rob'd you.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: Pray Sir make his Mittimus, I'le hang him if there were no more of the race of all mankind.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: But why do you believe it Sir!

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Why do I believe it Sir?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Why, why, why, because I do believe it.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: But I must have some proofs.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Did you see him dig where my money was hidden?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Oh yes Sir, why should I say so else? Where did you lay your money?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: In the Garden.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Ay there I saw him digging: What was your money in?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: In a Chest.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Why there's the business, now I saw him have a Chest, and the very same Chest you mean.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: What manner of Chest is it?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: What manner of one: 'Sdeath I shall be snap'd!

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: How is it made?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Why 'tis made—'tis made very like a kind of a Chest, extraordinary like a Chest.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: But how?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Why 'tis a great Chest.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Mine is a little one. Oh my Gold!

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Ay so was this in it self, but for what it contained it was a great one, and was so heavy that I am sure it made him puffe and blow to carry it.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: It must be the same, mine is very heavy.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Hold a little pray, what Colour is it of?

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Of what Colour.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Why it is of a colour, a certain Colour, I know not what a deus they call it, but really it is very pretty Colour, for a chest, that's the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Was it not a red?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No, no, mine's a green one.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Lord, you are so hasty, a reddish green I was going to say.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: The same Sir; pray make his mittimus, and let him be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: Here he comes, let him not discover this of me; perhaps hee'l confess it.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Come you Villain, come near and confess your wickednesse, your abominable action.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What do you mean Sir?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh horrid traytor, do you not blush?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Has he heard any thing of his daughter and me; for what should I blush Sir?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh impudence, as if he knew not what I meant; but all your villany is discover'd: oh wretch, to come into my house to betray me, and abuse my goodnesse with so infamous an action!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir, since you have discover'd me, I'le make no more excuses.

sp.speaker: Iames.
sp.p: That I should guess so right when I swear at a venture: I told you Sir, hee'd confesse.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: He ha's confess'd in part, but we must have more yet▪

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It was my designe to tell you of this, but I stay'd for a happier opportunity, and I beseech you be not angry' till I give my reasons.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: Oh abominable insolence, he would be giving me reasons for his infamous theft, like an impudent Thiefe.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: These Titles are none of mine, and you'l find, if you examine it, that my crime is pardonable.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: Oh devill, pardonable, to take away my soul, my life, my blood!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am in a condition to do your blood no wrong, and to make full reparation for this pretended injury.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: Oh you overjoy me, will you make restitution.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Your honour shall be fully satisfyed.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: Pox on my honour, I don't talk of my honour. But what could incite you to such action?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Love.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: A pox on your love, admirable love indeed, love of my broad pieces.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
No sir, it is not your Gold that I care for, let me but enjoy
what I have already, and I care for nothing in the world beside.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh intollerable insolence, he justifies his theft, and would keep what he has stollen. He distracts me, Sir you shall be hang'd, drawn and quarter'd, before you shall keep the least part of it.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: No Sir, you must not keep what you have got, by your favour.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: With your favour Sir, but I must; we have mutually engaged our faiths, and are now married, and nothing but death shall part us.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: Ingaged his faith, and married to my Chest: [aside.] 'tis enough, make his Mittimus, that he may be hang'd, and so be divorced from it.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Here is some mystery: where is this Treasure you have taken?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Here in the house.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Have you not broke it up?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Broke her up; better words Sir, or I shall forget my respect to you; I assure you shee's too honest.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: How my Chest of money too honest.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Her fair eyes have inspired in me a more refined passion.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: The Faire eyes of my chest.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I see Sir 'tis in vaine to conceale the truth any longer. 'Tis not a quarter of an Houre since your daughter, and I were married in Covengarden; and without a Portion.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh devil, is that affront added to my losse?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Without portion, consider that Sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Make his Mitt • mus, you shall be hang'd you Villaine, send him to the Gatehouse quickly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: How be hang'd! I assure you, though I stole your daughter, 'twas with her own consent.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: But you have confest a more capital theft; or if you had not, 'tis sworn against you, and I must send you to the Gaol.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! what do I hear? S • r, •• veou had any affection for me, hear me now; this Gentleman is a man of Quality and Fortune.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: A curse on him, he has rais'd his Fortune on my ruines, and for his Quality 'twill bring him to the Gallows.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: For Heaven's sake Sir use no extremity on him, I consented to all he did; if there be a fault committed against you, I am equally guilty, and will suffer with him.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Heaven! my own Daughter guilty of such an action, she shall be hang'd, send her to the Gaol immediately; no less then six thousand broad pieces at a time.

sp.speaker: Th • odora.
sp.p: Sir, I underotand you not.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh cunning Baggage! look you Mr. Iustice, she understands me not; I'le have her hang'd, my own Daughter Rob me.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Rob you! I am amaz'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sure Sir, you are not compos mentis.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: I am sorry to find ye guilty of so great a Fellony, I must send ye both to the Goal without Bail or Mainprize.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Brother, I heard you were in this condition, and came to rescue you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh Villian! are you come to heighten my affliction with the sight of you?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Sir, I come about a little business that concerns you.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Business with me? you insolent Rebel, what can that be.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Sir, the money is right.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What money you impertinent Ass?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: The broad pieces that were in the Garden, they are just six thousand; and I'le give you an acquittance under my hand for them.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: O Devil, had you them?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: They were received by my order, to my own proper use and behoo • e; I say Received per me Theodore.

sp.speaker: Golding.
sp.p: strikes at Theodore. O Barbarous insolence, I will cut your throat.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Nay, good Neighbour keep the peace.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p:
I cannot keep the peace, I will not keep the peace▪
let the peace keep its self; 'tis impossible to keep the peace.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: By your leave Sir, you must keep the peace, and not be Judge in your own case.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Send him to Gaol then presently.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Be patient, and I will.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Why would you have the Conscience to hang your Son?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Give me my Gold, and I'le spare your life.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: No Sir, your Gold is in sure hands, 'tis held in Mortmain.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Then I will hang you Rogue, make his Mittimus.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: You may please to remember, that there is a Colledge Lease of 4 hundred Pounds a year, that you hold only by my life; you will lose that (if you hang me) besides your broad pieces, of which you shall never have one by Heaven.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Nay then, I cannot be in a worse condition than I am; make hast Sir with his Mittimus.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: 'Tis a making.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Hold Sir, you must not make it, I did not St • al the Gold; I did but Sieze upon't for the Kings use.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: By Heaven, I owe the King not a farthing, I paid the last assessment, it went to my heart I am sure; and yet, to say truth, the Assessors have stretch'd their consciences against the King all over England, God bless them: Have you the impudence to say I owe the King money?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Assist me Brother. [To Bellamour.] [To Gold.] Do you think Sir the King will let you commit [Softly.] Treason for nothing?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Treason.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: There are Arms and Ammunition in the Vault Sir, if you be pleas'd to remember.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Have a care what you do Sir, Treason will fall heavy upon a rich man; you will be an excellent morsel for a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Have ye the impudence to speak of a Plot ye drew me into, ye brace of Traitors and Villains?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p:
Sir I know nothing of a Plot, not I, but my Brother and I can swear we saw Arms and Ammunition put in a
Vault; and we know from whom they were Receiv'd, and the consideration too. We shall find friends Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir Release the Gold, and make no more ado; if it should be found out that we know of the Plot, we should be pardon'd, for bringing in so rich and Capital an offender; but you would find no more mercy, than ever you shew'd to one that forfeited a Morgage.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: A curse on these Villains, I am caught in my own snare; they are in the right, I shall be sure to be hang'd, but if I were sure they were to be hang'd with me, it were no matter: But Son, are you in earnest? will you not give me some of my Gold again?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Not one piece by heaven, and pray Sir believe I deal fairly with you, that I ask no more; you know, I have not had a shilling of you these dozen years, 'tis time now to gather my Arrears.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: What will become of me? I must either lose my money or my life, I know not which is best; I think I must go hang my self, for fear of being hang'd.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: What shall I send him to Goal?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: No, let it alone, I must forgive the Rogue for this time.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: And do you release me of the money, before all these witnesses?

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes yes, but you cursed Villain I will be reveng'd on you, I'le marry Isabella, get Children and disinherit you of all the rest of my Estate.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Now since you have Releast me, look in your Chests in the Vault, and you will find nothing but Lumber.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: And was it no Plot you drew me into?

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: No by heaven, I but pretended it, and your hard usage forced me to these extreamities.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh unheard of Villain, I will go marry Isabella instantly, and I hope you will hang your self.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Stay Sir, I have one thing more to ask of you. This Lady and I are Married; and beg your pardon, and your blessing.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: Sir I beg your blessing and your pardon: Heaven would have it thus, and I could not help it.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: 'Sdeath and Hell! Married! you two Married!

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: 'Tis now too late to perplex your self.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Oh Treacherous wretches! Oh this Engine of the Devil, Cheatly with her damn'd Countess of Puddle-Dock.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Will you give us your blessing Sir? we kneel for it.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: Yes, I will give you my blessing.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: I shall receive it joyfully.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: May all the curses e're attended Marriage fall on you.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: Oh impious wish.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: We are obliged to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: May invincible impotence possess you, raging Lust her, and tormenting jealousie both of ye.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: For shame Neighbour be not so wicked.

sp.speaker: Gold.
sp.p: May the perpetual spirit of contention wait on ye, may ye never in your lives agree in one thing; may the name of quiet ne're be heard betwixt ye; and to compleat all, may ye never be assunder: and so Farewel.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: I'le after him, and try if I can mollifie him.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: Dear Sister, I am infinitely happy in my relation to you.

sp.speaker: Bellamour
sp.p: To himself.] It must be so. Oh heaven! it is my Sister (though I have not seen her these nine years) yet she has so much of her former Countenance remaining, that I am sure 'tis she.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Dear Isabella, here is a worthy. Gentleman you must call Brother.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have a neerer Title to her than what you can give me, she's my own Sister Isabella.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: This is wonderful.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: Indeed I had an Elder Brother beyond Sea, but we (having not seen him in nine years, nor heard from him these fifteen months) concluded him dead.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: (To his great grief) my younger Brother will find it otherwise.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: But is it possible! are you my Brother? indeed you have some resemblance of my Father, when he was living.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If you be Sir William Raines his Daughter of the North (as I am sure you are) I am your Brother; but thou wert too young when I left England; to have any impressions left of me now.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: My dear Brother, I am convinced, this is a happy hour, this will revive my dear Mother, who has kept her Chamber ever since my Fathers death.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: My dear Brother, now you are doubly so, but friendship yet shall be the stricter tye.

sp.speaker: Theodora.
sp.p: This is a wonderful and happy union of our Families.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: To shew you more clearly I am your Brother, (though my Father died without a Will) I know it was his intention to give you five thousand Pounds, which upon my honour you shall have.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: This is generosity in the highest point; but I was rich in the possession of my Isabella, beyond the thoughts of Dowry; but if I live to have my Fathers Estate, faith I'le be even with you.

sp.speaker: Isabella.
sp.p: This noble offer confirms me, you are my Brother; but why did you so long conceal your self?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That my dear Theodora can best tell you. But let us hast to see my afflicted Mother.

sp.speaker: Consta • le.
sp.p: They say the Justices Worship is here Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: The Constable with Squeeze! pray lets stay a moment after our Comedy, that ends so pleasantly, in hopes to see a Farse.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Heaven! what confusion am I in, and besides my bones are all loose with the fall last night.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: What's the matter Mr Constable?

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: Why Sir, this old Gentleman (not having the fear of God before his eyes) by the malice and instigation of the Devil, did yesternight vi & armis, contrary to the Peace of our Soveraign Lord the King, his Crown and Dignity; commit carnal copulation with one Mris Lettice.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The Stile of an Inditement.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: How now Mr. Squeeze, is the snare fallen upon you? can you help a man to three or four hundred Pound at fifty in the hundred, with good security?

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: You are very merry Sir, 'tis well if you have cause. Oh! Mrs. Cheatly what shall I do? my reputation is ruin'd, I am undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Oh Sir, there is more affliction for you yet, your Son lost fifty Pound last night, and Married a wench, one Mrs. Ioyce, that was kept by Alderman Do-Little.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Oh Heaven! all my misfortunes come together; this added to the other, will distract me.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: This is for your damn'd Brokeage and Use.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Could you not have brib'd the Constable?

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: He durst not let me go for fear of the Bullies? what shall I do; what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: I would be loath to put you to inconvenience, but if you would own my Daughter for your wife, it would soon preserve or at least repair your credit.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: She says true.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: And if you would really make her your wife, you would be fully reveng'd on your Son for his rash Marriage.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Ha, that's true again directly.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: If you do it not, the poor Girle will be ruin'd for ever in her reputation; which you know is her support at present.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: She is in the right, there is no way to save my reputation but this; if my disgrace should be published, no Godly Citizen will trust me; old men in this Town had as good marry their wenches, for they stand 'em in more money, and they keep 'em as long as if they were their wives.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Mr. Squeeze. here's your Lady, pray restore her Red Stocking, and take your own Black one; Oh Theodore, thou art gone the way of all flesh, I hear thou't Married.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: I am Sir, for all your instructions to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p:
Then thou art a lost man; yet faith 'tis as Pretty a
Girle for a fortnights, use or so, as a man could wish.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I find this Bully has the common place wit of all the young Fops in this Town; in Railing against Marriage.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Now art thou, Theodore, for a year condemn'd to eat and drink, go to Playes, to Church, and lie with thy own wife most unreasonable; But 'tis but having a little patience, and we shall have you amongst us again, as honest a sinner as the best of us.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: O Lord, here's my Father, I am so affraid of him.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Bear up to him, you say you have two hundred Pound a year left by an Aunt, which he can't touch.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay, I have so.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Stand up and own your wife to him; then besides 'twill vex the heart of Theodora to see how you have bob'd her.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay, I think so, (do you understand me?) I hope 'twill break her heart, de' see?

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Sir, here's your Son and his Lady, come to ask your blessing.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Oh you infinite Rascal!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Rascal Sir, I am the Son of a Scrivener, and they say I take mightily like my Father too.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Oh Villain! marry a Whore, out of my sight.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: A Whore Sir, I vow to God I scorn your words, do you mark me, she's as Pretty a civil young Lady, and I am sure I had her Maiden-Head, had I not my dear?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Yes indeed my dear, the best I had for you.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Oh infamous Villain! marry a Strumpet?

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Sir, I'd have you kick'd if you were not my Father-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: Dare to speak one ill word more of my Cousin, and I'le cut your Throat, old Sot.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: I am horrible affraid of this Hector; but I will be Reveng'd of the Rogue my Son.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: Now Madam Lettice I hope you'l own me to be equal at least with your Ladyship, Mr. Tim. has made me an honest woman; ther's more that you are.

sp.speaker: Rant.
sp.p: Farewel Theodore, thou art no more a man of this world; Marriage alters some men, and makes them forget their friends, as much as Perferment does

sp.speaker: Hazard.
sp.p: But I hope he has more grace.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: No more of your senseless Railing against Marriage, 'tis dull and common.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: There is no mollifying of your Father, he's run out in a rage; he has shut himself in his Closset, and will not be spoke to; Constable what makes you here?

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: Sir we have brought an old Gentleman here before you, upon suspition of Fornication, an please your Worship.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Whom, Mr. Squeeze! can a man of your years be guilty of Fornication?

sp.speaker: Constable.
sp.p: Sir, we took him leaping out of a Window half undress'd, and for haste he had puton a Red Silk-stocking of the Gentlewomans from whom he rose:

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Is this true?

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I was in bed with this Gentlewoman, but she's my wife; and I hope that's no offence.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.p: Your wife.

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Yes, and before all this company I a vow her to be so.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: O fie for shame Sir, marry a Strumpet

sp.speaker: Squeeze.
sp.p: Peace you insolent Rascal.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Lettice, I wish thee joy of thy old Rascal.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: I thank you Mr. Theodore. Now Mrs. Ioyce I hope you think not your self my equal: Down on your knees huswife and ask me blessing.

sp.speaker: Ioyce.
sp.p: I scorn your words, I shall never endure to call you Mother-in-Law while I live.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Madam Isabella, I wish you much joy with this Gentleman, and he is young enough, and handsom enough to give you good store on't.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Mrs. Cheatly, to shew my gratitude to you, I have a hundred pieces ready for you; and Robin, you I will make my particular care.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Sir, to shew you that I have taken some care of you, I have provided Fiddles for you.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Let 'em enter, wee'l borrow my Fathers house for a Dance; for perhaps we shall never come in it again.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: What say you Mrs. Cheatly, shall you and I marry, or continue to love on as we did?

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: I am very indifferent Robin, take thy own choice.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Why then as you were.

sp.speaker: Cheatly.
sp.p: Content.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Strike up.

sp.speaker: Theodore.
sp.p: Now we have done, I must confess I have transgress'd in my duty to my Father, which I could not help; unless I would have neglected a greater, which I ought to your Beauty my dear Isabella, and my Love; and I hope
sp.l: My passion will a just excuse be thought:
What is urg'd on by love, can be no fault.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: WHen Sieges now by Poets are prepar'd,
And Love and War 'gainst Nations is declar'd;
When Affrica and Asia are not spar'd,
By some who in Rime will all the World o'rerun,
Who in their Conquests will no Country shun,
Not scaping the Mogul, nor Prester Iohn,
No American Prince is in his Throne secure,
Not Totty Potty Moy himself is sure:
But may the fury of their Rime endure,
Nay in time each Prince in Guinny will be sought,
And under these Poetick Fetters brought;
And we shall see how th' black Rogues lov'd and fought.
When such great things are for the Stage design'd,
We fear this trifle will no favour find.
But as a fop that's dress'd in Masquerade,
Will any place with impudence invade,
And little rambling Punks dare be so rude,
Among the best of Ladies ro intrude:
So Poets sure, though ill, may be allow'd
Among the best in Masquerade to crowd.
Our Poet who wrote this Incognito,
Does boldly claim this priviledge as his due;
He presses in, and will not be kept out,
Though he deserves to stand amongst the rout,
Those fifteen hundred Poets who have writ,
And never could have one Play acted yet.
But now hee's in, pray use him civilly,
Let him, what e're▪ he sayes, unquestion'd be,
According to the Laws of Masquerade,
Those sacred Laws by dancing Nations made,
Which the young Gallants sure will ne're invade.
If ye resolve that yee'l be angry now,
Ye vent your spleen upon an unknown Foe;
Or if he be not, yet yee'l make him so:
But if a kindness to him ye intend,
And though 't deserves it not, the Play commend:
Each man for ought he knows is kind to's friend.
